Only game to ever make me rage uninstall. 9/10 overall.

After spending so many hours playing this game, I can confidently say that this is the BEST roguelike game.
DIFFICULTY: 7.5 / 10
Undoubtedly, the first hours of the game will be spent on the first - second floor. The variety and diversity of ETG never ceases to amaze me even after so many hours. The enemies are smart, they turn the tables and can squeeze you. Of course, over time you will get used to it and be able to play almost without damage, but the beginning in ETG is countless deaths.
Roll - good and evil.
I had 3 phases of opinion about the roll:

"Damn, immortality during a roll?! That's imbued!"

“I hate rolling! I always fly straight into a bullet or into a hole! I’d rather just walk!”

“Oh, a roll is good, but the main thing is to watch where you do it, and sometimes It's better to just pass"

And so, I ABSOLUTELY recommend playing ETG, because the different mechanics of the characters make them really different, the rooms and floors are complex, the bosses are interesting, the graphics are beautiful.
What did I NOT like? Perhaps the fact that the 5 main floors and secret floors have no analogues, the locations quickly become boring.
The boss rush appears at the moment when it is no longer needed and you are already accustomed to most bosses, and besides, it also requires payment.
Some achievements are strange and are obtained in an extremely dubious way through actions that you are unlikely to do during a regular race.

In conclusion, I want to say that I absolutely recommend playing ETG for people who are partial to bagels, because people who have not played this genre will find the game too difficult and you will most likely quit it.
I wish you good luck...however, skill is much more important here!

Enter the Gungeon : By Triple F

"Enter the Gungeon" is, without a shadow of a doubt, a spectacular masterpiece in the world of indie gaming. From the very moment I stepped into the whimsical, trigger-happy world of Gungeon, I was utterly captivated. This game isn't just a run-and-gun, it's a relentless barrage of creativity and fun that keeps you hooked for hours on end.

The first thing that grabs you by the eyeballs is the game's unique and visually striking art style. Every pixel is a work of art, from the quirky characters to the intricately designed firearms. It's like playing a Saturday morning cartoon, only with way more bullets and explosions. The attention to detail is astounding; you can't help but admire the loving craftsmanship that went into creating this world.

But "Enter the Gungeon" isn't just about looks – it's got the game-play to match and exceed expectations. The core mechanic of dodging and rolling through torrents of bullets is exhilarating, making every gunfight feel like a high-octane dance of survival. The controls are razor-sharp, and mastering them is a satisfying journey in itself. As you progress, you'll find yourself weaving through bullet hell scenarios that require a blend of quick reflexes and clever strategy, making each encounter feel fresh and exciting.

The sheer variety of guns and items in the Gungeon is staggering. From the basic pea-shooter to the ludicrously overpowered makeshift cannon, every firearm has its quirks, making experimentation an absolute joy. It's hard not to cackle maniacally when you discover a new weapon or unlock a game-changing item. And don't even get me started on the synergies! The combinations of items and guns can lead to some absurdly fun and powerful load-outs that keep the game-play endlessly entertaining.

Speaking of endless entertainment, "Enter the Gungeon" features rogue-like elements that ensure no two runs are the same. The procedural generation of levels keeps you on your toes, and the unpredictable boss fights are both challenging and satisfying. Each character you can play as comes with their own unique abilities and story-lines, adding layers of replay-ability. The excitement of discovering new secrets, hidden chambers, and quirky NPCs is boundless.

The soundtrack deserves special mention. The music in "Enter the Gungeon" is a glorious symphony of bullets and beats, perfectly complementing the intense action on-screen. It's one of those rare soundtracks that you'll find yourself humming long after you've put the controller down.

And let's not forget the humor! The game is packed with puns, references, and quirky dialogue that will keep you grinning from ear to ear. It's clear that the developers had a blast creating this world, and that joy is infectious.

In conclusion, "Enter the Gungeon" is a bullet-hell ballet that's as fun to watch as it is to play. Its unique blend of pixel art charm, relentless action, and endless surprises make it a true gem in the indie gaming universe. Whether you're a fan of rogue-likes, twin-stick shooters, or just looking for a game that oozes personality and fun, "Enter the Gungeon" is an absolute must-play. So, lock and load, dodge those bullets, and dive headfirst into this quirky, chaotic, and utterly fantastic adventure. You won't be disappointed!

So, this one actually took a while to 'grow' on me. This wasn't one of those games that just immediately hooked me and had me playing non-stop.. It was the kind where I played a little then decided I wanted to play something else. I'd come back to bum around the game a little, then go play something else. For a while I had decided I really didn't want to play it anymore at all. Then, I guess, at a certain point it kinda clicked, and that's when I racked up my hours of playtime.

Here's the issue with this one - a lot of roguelike games like this, you've got a certain amount of meta progression - depending on how well you play each round, you'll earn some kind of 'progression currency,' and once you go back to the main menu, you can buy health upgrades or attack upgrades or whatever... Well, the meta progression in ETG is a lot more basic. I may not have progressed far enough to find out otherwise, but so far I'm finding that I'm not upgrading my total health, attack power, or anything like that, but rather just unlocking certain guns and items for future runs. So while you might unlock a great gun for future runs, you're always going to start with the same basic stats, and you just kinda hope you get that cool gun you unlocked in each run.

This was partly why I kept stopping playing - most games of this type give you that sense of making progress. You won't get very far, but you get that progression currency and buy a health upgrade, so the next round you get a little farther, get a little more progression points, buy an even better upgrade, get even farther. In ETG, it's all play skill - you only get farther because you get better at playing. While that is a nice challenge, it just wasn't as fun to me.

I kept coming back, though, because the gameplay is actually pretty fun. There are quite a few guns to be collected (more as you unlock them), it's bullet-hell-ish without being completely overwhelming, and the levels (procedurally-generated) are 'different' enough that you don't wind up feeling like you're just doing different versions of the same thing over and over. 

The old-school-ish graphics are fun and entertaining, the sounds are silly and engaging, and the world has lots of flavor. It's also pretty darn silly. The lore in the game is actually fun to read - in between runs, you can read silly background facts about the enemies, the different guns, the items you can collect, and so on. And some of it is just absurd. (Such as the bullet-shaped gun which fires gun-shaped bullets, each of which fire bullets at bullet-shaped enemies carrying guns that shoot bullets at you. Yes. That.)

So while I do give this game a 'thumbs up,' it is with a caveat: if you're anything like me, you may not really 'get into' this game right away, or you might lose interest altogether. This game would probably be sitting in the back corners of my library, untouched, if I hadn't randomly decided to give it another go at a certain point. Because again, while it's fun, that real lack of meta progression (besides 'unlocking items that you can find in the gungeon in the future') kinda threw me off.

But, now that I've put in a decent amount of time, I've had quite a bit of fun with it, have enjoyed myself, and have gained a little skill, so I do halfway ok in the world.

Worth full price? I don't know. I'd wait for a sale before pulling the trigger, because I could see some people giving up (like I did for a while) and I'd hate for people to be disappointed. You may find in the end that you believe the game to be well worth the fifteen bucks, but why take a risk? Just wait for a sale or buy a bundle or something, just in case you don't.

TLDR: Feels like it's unfinished, I have no idea why people like it, this is genuinely the most overrated game I've ever played imo, and if this was the first roguelite I ever played I would never touch the genre again. 

The reason that this beta build garbage managed to become not only overwhelmingly positive but one of the most well regarded indie games I know of is so far beyond me the only reason I know it exists at all is that it was recently picked up by Voyager 2. The bosses are bullshit, the enemies are bullshit (fuck you lead maiden), the game itself is more focused on overdone references than providing a playable experience, losing a fight feels like dying for no reason, winning a fight is either "Wow, that worked?" or "Wow, that shouldn't have worked." and worst of all, none of the guns are satisfying enough to be actually fun. They always kill in 2 to 3 more shots than you expect, and anytime you find one you actually like, you'll run out of ammo within this floor or the next and you'll probably never see it again. If you want a fun roguelite shooter where your arsenal slowly becomes more and more powerful against an endless army, try either Atomicrops, if you've got a soft spot for strategy, time management, or farming in games, Risk of Rain 2, if you like hero shooters, modding things to high heavens, giving yourself epilepsy tests, and interesting lore, or Vampire Survivors, if you like turning your brain off and shiny colors. All of them are far, far better than this nonsense.

Every community I've visited over the past few years has been convinced Enter the Gungeon was inadvertently designed to waste its time, or didn't respect the players as much as it perhaps should have. I never felt this way towards EtG myself; I think it's a very well-paced and well-designed game. In fact, it's the epitome of Roguelite game design - design that has not waned in the face of competition for 8 years on the market now.

The unique presentation of EtG certainly played a big part in its appeal to me. In the pursuit of the gun that can kill the past, players are dropped into a dungeon where everything is gun or bullet-themed; the stages ("chambers") are all plays on gun-related themes or words. The elevators are big bullets, the enemies are shells or cartridges, even the bosses are made of guns or are named after guns, like the Ammoconda or Dragun.

Currency is dealt in casings, cursed enemies are aptly named "jammed" instead of "damned"; this corny theme reveals a well thought-out universe with a sense of consistency to it, making you want to see more of what it has to offer. The spritework is downright gorgeous, and the game runs well. Significant effort went into making each stage feel like a lively micro-cosmos, as if the players have intruded on the inhabitants' daily lives by simply being present.

Tables are laden with food and drink, getting scattered across the floor as shots whiz past them. Crates, pots, vases, barrels and armor stands outline each room, soaking up projectile damage if taken cover behind, or shattering if bumped into. The walls gradually fill with bullet holes when shot, characters leave dust clouds in their trail, and the mayhem left in their wake further takes form in spent bullet casings, spilled liquids, and enemy corpses on the ground.

This is what sets EtG apart from other games in the genre - the attention to detail. The player and the enemies are not the sole focus of the stage; great effort went into making each firefight feel like it came straight out of a movie. Not all objects and particles are there just for show, though: there is purpose to the braziers, lanterns, liquid drains in each room, indirectly aiding in dealing with your opponents during the fight.

Explosive barrels can be kicked across the floor, then neutralized with a shot or a roll depending on the desired outcome. Levers can be pulled to drop chandeliers or rocks on top of unsuspecting foes. Barrels full of liquid gas or toxic poison can help deny areas from enemies if utilized to their fullest extent. There are holes in the floor that foes can be pushed into, or spikes, fires, crush traps players must be careful not to trigger.

Tables and coffins can further be used during battle to create temporary cover, or a means to gain invulnerability if slid across. The latter incorporates the dodge-roll mechanic, a neat multi-purpose design that takes after the dash from other games in the genre. Not only does a player gain invulnerability by dodge-rolling, they also neutralize hazards in doing so, and can leap over traps and pits as if they were jumping. On top of that, the roll is able to deal damage.

Enemies then appropriately react to these actions, taking cover behind tables themselves, or shooting where they predict the player will move next. The AI is competent - it telegraphs attacks well, and tries to shoot explosives near players if any are found within their vicinity. Some enemies might feature multiple attack patterns, or explode into revenge-bullets on death, and some can even be used to kill other enemies in stark contrast to other Roguelites.

I would like to point out a flaw within EtG's design, and that is the health scaling used to strengthen the enemies in later game stages. In my eyes, it serves as an unnecessary gear-check, an artificial barrier that stems from the weapons becoming less efficient the longer you play. I'm glad new stages offer new enemies to face off against, however I don't appreciate old enemies gaining more health and resilience to my guns.

That said, the weapon selection aiding in dealing with these foes is so vast, their health often does not matter. Some weapons take after their real-life counterparts, such as the M16 or the AK-47, others are completely imaginary or abstract. As with any other good Roguelite, there are plenty of references to other videogames, and weapons can even synergize with others in your loadout, empowering one if another is picked up.

You'd think that with hundreds of weapons on offer, the selection would get repetitive, but most weapons are surprisingly unique and efficient. Some fire in bursts of varying degrees of accuracy and rates of fire, some are semi-automatic or require charging, others fire in a spread or in a beam configuration. Many interact with the debuff system, causing enemies to burn, freeze, get slowed, poisoned, or even turn into harmless chickens.

More importantly - and this is something I’ve never seen another game do - is their interaction with the reload system. Many weapons will switch phases upon reloading, changing the behavior of the weapon to a more damaging mode with less ammo, or a burst-fire mode, or a different projectile entirely. This makes you adapt to the weapon you’re carrying and gives it a unique personality or quirk.

I believe the main issue players have with this game is the amount of drops initially being very limited, forcing them to fight the first boss with sub-optimal weaponry, making for a very tedious fight. I do also believe over the course of the game’s lifespan the devs actively attempted to address this issue, and as far as I'm concerned, they did so successfully.

Players start with one key for one out of two chests that spawn per level, and during the first floor they further gain enough currency to buy another key or another weapon, with both guaranteed to spawn in the first shop. This can potentially get them rolling (no pun intended) provided luck plays in their favor. There are other means with which players can get weapons, such as discovering secrets or playing minigames.

I personally compensate for this design by playing one of the two characters who sport two starter weapons; all the characters would have been given the same treatment if it were up to me. Switching weapons and using an Active diversifies each engagement and adds to the decision-making aspect of combat. In that, the design of the other characters remains lacking, but provided how easy it is to obtain new weapons I don't give this much significance.

The Actives and Passives are somewhat forgettable, I assume intentionally. They take a back seat to the weapon selection the game puts on offer. Many of the Passives raise max health or improve damage and accuracy, which is pretty boring. Many Actives are about throwing or setting down explosives to temporarily boost damage output. It will mainly be the weapon selection that will draw your interest and provide a reason for you to keep playing.

EtG is a very accessible game, and does many things right that its predecessors do not - for example, teleporting between explored areas, which I believe this game pioneered. Currency magnetizes to you when you finish a room, you can drop, sell, or combine weapons you don't need, and gain health ups by defeating bosses flawlessly. If not for its other strengths, it's also a highly replayable game, thanks to its strong meta-progression system and roster of NPCs.

It's quirky and humorous, I honestly don't see a reason not to recommend this - provided you can stomach the slower-burning runs, and the occasional run-in with bad RNG.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Come on you have to know what you're getting in to. Enter the Gungeon's reputation precedes it it's just that good. ETG stands at the top with some of the best roguelikes of all time. Personally my top 3 would have to be Risk of Rain 2, Enter the Gungeon, and Slay the Spire. There really are no better roguelikes out besides Binding of Issac, but I haven't personally played it yet. ETG just has a super fun arcade vibe with an incredible amount of content for the price. The bullet hell aspect is insane and it will make you rage for sure. I genuinely could not think of any downsides to this game it says what it is up front and it delivers in every aspect. You won't regret it.

Torture. I can see how it can get fun when you gitgud, but it is too hard. So you are just banging your head against it until you learn all the patterns while playing like a female canine. Floor 1-2 you barely get anything when luck is bad so the learning experience is terrible, you literally go through the motion to Floor 3 and then die. I'm done.

Whats the point of having a hub when the unlocks doesn't do anything to help you ease into it when you start? It is mainly stuff for people that can already clear it, shortcuts, more gunzzz, challenge runs. The game play is reliant on having a range of fun guns, so your base set is poor. Enter The Gungeon offers an exhilarating journey through a world filled with  a diverse range of enemies that keep every run feeling fresh and challenging. The game's roster of adversaries spans from the quirky to the downright badass, creating an engaging experience that caters to both casual and hardcore players.

One of the standout features of Enter The Gungeon is the variety of enemies encountered throughout the game. Some foes feel like they were tailor-made to be your personal punching bag, allowing for satisfying and strategic combat encounters. On the flip side, there are adversaries designed to make  every run a living hell, pushing you to adapt and improve your skills.

While the character selection may seem limited at first glance, the game compensates with an extensive arsenal of guns and items to choose from. Initially, I was disappointed by the lack of character diversity, but as I delved deeper into the game, I found solace in the vast array of weapons and power-ups. The developers have done a commendable job of ensuring that each playthrough feels unique, offering a plethora of tools to experiment with and discover new, exciting combinations.

One thing to note is the inclusion of intentionally weak and useless guns and items. While these additions may induce frustration initially, they contribute to the game's charm by encouraging players to experiment and find unexpected ways to turn the tide in their favor. It's all part of the learning curve that makes Enter The Gungeon both challenging and rewarding.

One of the game's highlights is the presence of guns that can truly turn the tables. From the awe-inspiring to the downright absurd, there are firearms capable of obliterating bosses with a single, well-placed shot. This element injects an extra layer of excitement into each run, keeping players on their toes as they hope to stumble upon these game-changing weapons.

In conclusion, Enter The Gungeon is a must-play for fans of bullet-hell and roguelike genres. The diverse range of enemies, coupled with an extensive arsenal of guns and items, ensures that no two runs are ever the same. While character variety might be lacking, the game's emphasis on strategic combat and unexpected surprises more than makes up for it.

This game is absolutely unmatched in terms of replayability - even though you end up encountering the same type of enemies, fight the same set of bosses and visit the same floors over and over again, every round of the game just manages to stand out in its own way - either by giving you a gun, which demolishes anything that stands in your way, or, conversely, you facing a boss which has like a 0.1% chance to appear each run and that just ends up changing everything...
Yet despite that RNG aspect to the game, it rarely ever feels unfair to play - you can always combat any misfortune you face with enough skill. And the randomness is exactly what makes it so fun to play, you can never predict what outcome your next round will have, it could end up becoming your most elite round with the longest playtime ever where you manage to defeat all the bosses, or you might stumble onto an incredibly rare boss which has like a 0.1% chance to appear and changes the course of your entire run...

The developers did a phenomenal job with this one, one of my favorite games I've played in a while, there is so much to learn from how well this game manages to keep you coming back for more. At first I thought, it was just about defeating the dragon on the fifth floor, which was a journey in itself already, and that was it... Oh, little did I know, how much more there was to do out there! Guess I'll play one more round now.

This is a great game and I strongly recommend it. In particular I recommend this game and would [i]not[/i] recommend Exit The Gungeon, for anyone who's unsure of what to purchase.

[h2]The good[/h2]
The game is 99% skill-based. I'll get to the other 1% in a second, but rest assured that dying is almost always entirely your own fault. Items and guns are certainly impactful, but the biggest deciding factor is simply how good you are at shooting enemies and dodging enemy bullets. You will not roll into gamebreaking invincibility combos like in Isaac.

There is also strategy to be found in how and when to spend your resources. Arguably there is less in this regard than Isaac, but it's definitely there. This "meta" aspect is what Isaac mainly focuses on, while this game mostly focuses on skill and the actual gameplay instead. I like both, for different reasons.

There are "cheese limiters" in place and this is actually genius game design. When you get an ammo box and leave the room, the Resourceful Rat will come in pretty quickly to steal it. Same with keys. This prevents degenerate or boring strategies, like leaving all ammo pickups on the ground and then picking it up right before you leave the floor. This is also done with weapons and items, to prevent players from cheesing the game by swapping active items all the time. The Rat forces you to make meaningful decisions at that current moment... and the game even gives you a rather roundabout "out" to remove him from the current run if you wish. This means the developers can just balance the game normally and not have to worry about making mechanics too weak when un-cheesed, or making them too strong if cheesed.

After all these years, while writing this review, I just realized the Rat is a pun on him being an anti-cheese mechanic which I find endlessly amusing.

The game's art style is good. It works well, it looks charming, and the game clearly telegraphs dangers. Other than a single floor sprite in Level 5, I have never felt like I unfairly took damage from something I couldn't very clearly see... but more on that later.

The tutorial is good and serves as a good way to get people to learn the game. Big props for not just dropping people directly into the game until they learn by trial and error.

The game has plenty of secrets, but some are really hard to find. One is hidden in the tutorial which is a place people generally won't search in. I like the secrets. Secret rooms are hit or miss (especially their rewards vs. how hard they are to find) but I appreciate that they exist. The secret stages are fun and rewarding.

Rainbow Mode is interesting. I find that it makes the game too easy, but it's a fun alternative way to play the game. I just fear that newbies will be grasping at Rainbow Mode to get the unlocks, stick on it forever, and won't learn the game properly.

The soundtrack is fine. It's not very memorable, but it sets the tone and sounds good. It's not an absolute banger but it fits the game and I like it.

The technical aspects of the game are about as good as you can ask for. It runs well, runs at any resolution, runs at any framerate/refresh rate, and I have encountered zero bugs (even minor ones) in all my playthroughs. Big plus for letting controller users manually force certain button prompts, too! If the game doesn't recognize my PS4 controller as being a PS4 controller, I can just force the button prompts into the PS4 icons.

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
I said the game is 99% skill-based, for a reason. To properly "beat" the game, you must first work towards completing The Bullet That Can Kill The Past in your runs. This means doing a specific thing to get 1 out of 4 items, and then beating the first "final" boss while holding the item. You don't have to do them all in 1 run at the same time.

The problem is, acquiring 2 out of 4 of these items is RNG-based. One item needs flight or a liquid gun, the other item needs you to gather enough money before a specific floor. These are not guaranteed even if you play perfectly.

I like the concept that some of these items suck up resources like money or an active item slot, and I like that you might have to make a potentially dangerous detour on Floor 5 to turn these items in. Because it requires you to "punch above your weight" a little bit before you can proceed further into the game. But they could have handled the random aspects a little more gracefully.

Unlocking The Robot as a character is incredibly tedious. It's not hard - just really tedious. I question what value is added by having the Broken TV be [i]dropped[/i] when you roll. It's an annoyance at best and it feels like a cheap trick to catch you off-guard and force you to restart a few times. Mechanically speaking this would have been much more fun and interesting if it simply hogged an active item slot, and nothing else. If this isn't enough, maybe it should have just prevented you from picking up or using armor instead.

The game suffers from momentum just a little bit too hard. You do really poorly in the game and get very little rewards until you get over this "hump" and then you suddenly do [i]REALLY[/i] well because you're getting rewarded left and right. Getting hit by an enemy means they drop less/no money. Getting hit during a boss means you lose out on an HP upgrade. The rich get richer, the poor get clapped into more poverty.

This is a [i]positive[/i] thing for some people and it can feel rewarding to obtain proof that you beat bosses hitless, but I don't like the Master Round or "damage = no money" mechanic as a whole.

The game has "Magnificence" mechanics in place that prevent you from getting insanely lucky by getting a lot of high-quality chests or a whole bunch of pickups all at once, basically preventing you from steamrolling the game through luck alone. Problem being that Magnificence does not apply the other way around. There are safeguards in place against getting a whole bunch of red chests, but the game is perfectly willing to give you only brown and blue chests for the whole game if you get unlucky. This is a minor nitpick but it feels really cheap.

Pickup RNG isn't kept in check properly. This game is skill-based for the most part, and while the game guarantees you'll get randomly dropped pickups [i]eventually[/i], the game can still give you the middle finger and literally [i]refuse[/i] to give you any ammo pickups or keys, insisting on giving you only hearts and maybe some armor or glass guon stones the entire time. Or maybe the next run you get showered with 3 ammo boxes in a row that you can't even use because you're already full.

With ammo being this incredibly important in the game, they should have tracked it separately so that while you can still run out if you're not careful, you shouldn't be forced to play half the game with just the starter pistol.

Trap rooms feel bad. This is slightly lessened by the teleport mechanic existing, but a badly placed trap room is incredibly annoying and often leads to more damage than you oughta take just because you haven't wiki'd the best way to get past them yet.

The "on fire" debuff stays until you roll to put it out. This could have been made a little more obvious, perhaps a loading screen tip? The first time it happened to me was about 40 hours in (it's a rare status effect), and I just saw all my health drain away until I died. On a related note, some floors in Level 5 set you on fire and this isn't as clearly telegraphed as it probably should be.

A definite must-play for rogue-like lovers... and perhaps more. 
Remember: grass grows, birds fly, games come and go... yet the Gungeon remains.

This is what all roguelikes should strive to be, I'd even rank it over Spelunky (bars).

Fantastic little gem of a game, that imo beats Isaac in almost every aspect:
- runs are really tough but completely skill-dependent: as soon as you start growing into the mechanics you can beat the game with the shi t tiest guns (albeit it'll be a chore)
- artstyle is fantastic and nailed the D&D backdrop perfectly
- contrary to Isaac battles are very well balanced: you cannot 1shot all bosses and rooms as well as you don't have damage scale bosses which was a lazy ass cringe mechanic to combat being OP as hell with the right items. Even with great guns bosses are still a challenge and you need to time your dodges right, without it you will just perish
- crammed full of details that make each room exploration a treat, music is godlike
- near endless replayability due to how varied the RNG feels like here
- pop culture references feel done right, they're not in your face and will probably age a lot more gracefully than referencing rage comics and old memes (looking at you Edmund again)
- everything is shooting and guns: this has been referenced in countless reviews but it is a very important aspect, the humor and gun-ness of this game is just perfect, it's basically a giant homage to firearm culture and history

all in all my favourite roguelike at the moment and something I gladly fire up to let out 40 minutes of stress - if you liked Isaac I highly recommend grabbing this one as I view it to be superior in almost every way. Just don't be put off by the difficulty curve, it may seem impossible at first but trust me you'll git gud and see it through.

A must-have for anyone that enjoys roguelites. 

While it may not quite have the sheer number of items found in The Binding of Isaac, the core mechanics and gameplay loop are very finely tuned and dodging around the various enemies and boss bullet patterns never stops being enjoyable. The game can get very challenging but always feels fair.

Not to say there isn't significant variety either, as while the number of items and guns is lower there is arguably more variety to them. Many of the guns are very creative where a lot of the items in The Binding of Isaac are simply stat boosts. On top of that there are synergies available for almost every gun in the game, and these can range from stat boosts to completely changing how guns function, summoning a familiar, dual wielding or combining two guns together into a more powerful one. There are also quite a few different rare characters/rooms that can be found occasionally, as well as rare bosses/mini-bosses that occasionally show up.

This isn't even getting into the presentation side, which is very charming. The soundtrack is also good, not the best you'll ever hear but it's got some catchy tunes which are fitting. I just wish there was more variety, like unique boss themes for the final boss(es). All in all an excellent game well worth the price.

Easy to play but hard to master. This is the perfect game when you’re in the mood for a quick 30 minute run. 

It has loads of content, in the form of weapons, items, bosses, floors, and endings. There are multiple starting characters each with a different loadout supporting different styles of play (except melee, melee is a sin in this game). 

There are lots of secrets and unlockables as well, giving you a nice sense of progression in the game as you discover them. You will unlock thousands of unique items that you can find in your future runs. The other form of progression comes with experience: you will die a lot starting out, it takes a lot of time to learn attack patterns and enemy types. 

This game is THE best rougelike in my opinion. It’s always fast paced and you always have a chance of beating your run even if you get bad RNG. 

It’s very well priced at only $15 and has lots of content included.  The game has good quality pixel art and a majority of the guns are super smooth and fun to use.

The game has a pretty good modding community with tons of the bigger mods adding new versions of everything. Characters, items, enemies, floors, and bosses are some of the notable additions that come with the more popular mods. These can make the game feel fresh again after you feel the base game has nothing left to offer you.

The one flaw I have with this game is the slow start. In the beginning of the game you have to unlock EVERYTHING. All the cool weapons and items are locked until you can afford them. This can be a negative and a positive to some people, as it gives you a reason to play and want to progress, but at the same time limits your choices in the beginning.

Please try this game out, it’s an amazing bullet-hell and rougelike, and if you don’t like it after 2 hours, you can always refund it!

An instant classic. Enter the Gungeon is one of the most refined twin stick shooters i've ever had the pleasure of playing. Enter the Gungeon is most directly comparable to Nuclear Throne, being a twinstick shooter with touhou elements. Unlike Nuclear Throne, however, Gungeon is a more casual experience, which makes it a better game to pick up and play after an exhausting day at work, or when you just want to have fun. There are many weapons and items to unlock, from a wide variety of vendors, and a wide array of playable characters (including secret characters!) to use those weapons with. Of course, no twin stick roguelite would be complete without a rogue's gallery of bosses, which Gungeon also delivers on... Including secret bosses! 


Ultimately, Gungeon is one of the best "bang for your buck" games out there. It's a relatively cheap game that will give you a solid 50+ hours of replay value. Worth it for any steam library.

I've bought this game on 3 platforms and beaten it on all three, so my hours are probably way higher than Steam says. But the longer I've had this game, the more I appreciate it, and probably consider it one of my favorite games of all time.

A blend of bullets hell games and roguelikes that released soon after the success of Undertale (colloquially referred to as most people's first bullet hell game), Gungeon managed to be difficult enough for me at first that I gave up playing it after a month. I first got it on Switch after it received its final content update, so I already had access to all the QOL fixes and new content. I didn't see a lot of it though, since the game can be kind of tough. It's not Binding of Isaac levels of difficulty, but it can get borderline unfair at times.

Gungeon does offer some long term progression in the form of unlockable items and characters. Most items are bought with credits you earn by beating bosses, so even if you don't make it more than a floor or two in, you at least return with something. Some unlocks do require beating a challenge of some kind, but I would describe all but one of them as being pretty fair (what most would consider the final character to unlock, I think it was pretty difficult the first time.)

To get back to my point, I came around to this game because it's a roguelike that rewards you for getting better. The further you get, the more stuff you unlock in future runs, which you learn to use and then go even further. On my first run on Steam (which is my third playthrough) I've reached the point where I could kill the final regular boss and reach the end, so even at the very start, it is possible without any of that long term progression. But finding all the wacky items and trying everything really makes the game fun. Getting broken builds late game is always fun, and the game definitely let's you become overpowered. It can ruin the game at times, like trying to go back to playing normally after using some kind of godmode cheat in a game and now the game doesn't even feel fun because your dopamine receptors are fried.

Anyway, the game has hundreds of unique items and guns, referencing a wide range of media and weapons. From medieval crossbows to lightsaber assault rifles, the game finds funny ways to bring them all together.

Even the lore is good, surprisingly making a lot of sense in explaining why both those guns would exist under the same roof. The Gungeon exists in a wide universe that we may never see more of thanks to the radio silence from the developers, which is a huge shame. But the lore raises cool ideas and builds a world outside of the game that explains it well, and I honestly wish we could've seen more of it.

There are a few problems with the game, of course. Visibility can be an issue, as the game is actually a 3D environment rendered in Unity, so there's real lighting going on. Pitfalls can be so poorly illuminated that I still walk into them because I can't tell they're there to begin with.
Sometimes it still feels like things come down to RNG, even though the game does a very good job at minimizing the role luck plays in player success. Mostly this comes down to things like keys, money, or ammo not dropping when they're desperately needed, but most of the time you won't have to rely on the starting gun.
The four starting characters aren't balanced very evenly, and I think there's a pretty clear tier list of who is the best choice. I think its kind of unfortunate since they all have distinct identities, but their starting kits are just not useful enough to justify picking them. Unlockable characters have much stronger starting kits, arguably too strong compared to the main cast, but the new characters also have gimmicks that make them fun and refreshing to play.
Late into runs, most characters start to lose their identities though, at least when playing optimally. As you get more powerful items, you usually end up trying to find the same small batch of S or A tier guns to really annihilate the last bosses, but all the characters use them exactly the same. So while each character starts a run with a different playstyle, they all converge late game into the same optimal strategies revolving around the same high tier items. In some ways it is what Brimstone is to Binding of Isaac. Too good to pass up. but it can be repetitive.

There's a lot to love about the art in the game. Besides the hundreds of times designed, every floor has a unique theme. Enemies do get reused, but generally each floor tries to introduce new ones on top of the old, and by late run you only see much harder enemies. But every enemy has a fun design, every boss is unique. Many fun references from things like Dungeons and Dragons, Zelda, to the game Snake. They turned Snake into an entire boss (although it's kind of a hated boss, the concept is really cool.) Progressing through the game, there are times where I actually find the visuals to be really cool.
There's even cut content from the game which has the same level of polish, and it's a tragedy it'll never officially see the light of day.

Good time to transition to modding. The modding scene is big, although not as large as some other games. Not on the Steam Workshop, but on Nexus and the R2Mod Manager, there's some good ones. Even ones that restore the cut content. I find a lot of the mods to be pretty unbalanced compared to the base game, but there's a lot of fun items to try.

I don't know how to wrap this up. This game is so fun and I find myself returning to it more than almost any other game, and always having fun with it again. It's not perfect, but I feel like it comes close for me, riding that thin line that a roguelike needs to rely on randomly generated elements but gameplay which highly encourages players to improve their core techniques and skills, and still rewards them for it in both the short and long term. Even once you've mastered it all, it's still fun to return and start a fresh run and just dive through it again. I take breaks from it for sure, but I think I'll always come back to the Gungeon.

Hands down the best rogue-like game I have played. And that's "rogue-like" and not "roguelite". Nothing about this game gets easier as you play it (which is the main distinction between the two types).

You play as "the gungeoneer" with a choice of 4 initial characters, four more unlockable as you play. Every room is randomly generated and every floor has its own theme and set of enemies. The lower you go the more challenging the game gets. 

There is SO much to do in this game despite the repetitive nature of its gameplay. Unlocking new weapons(of which there is a ton) and items to use is such a joy. Almost every weapon is unique with references to different games, media, and memes alike. Every boss, enemy, and ally is either a gun pun or a reference to something; its amazing. 

The game, as I said before, does not get easier as you play but rather your skills get better. You start to learn enemy patterns, get a feel for the weapons and items, and learn which areas to avoid. The bullets don't get easier to dodge but instead you become fluid, dodging bullets left and right, ascending into a god of guns and destruction as you descend the into the gungeon. 

An amazing game. 10/10

edit: Y'all this is a an ancient review. Gungeon is not the same game it was on 2016.  A lot of the changes to the game from there almost seemed to directly address many of these complaints. Maybe one day I'll go back to it and write a new review but lol this has no value outside of a historic footnote.

I'll even swap it to a positive review. The fact that Gungeons and Dragons seemed to directly address the points below is super cool and I respect the devs a lot for it, even if I haven't gotten around to play it.

----- 2016 Gungeon Negative Review Below ------

There is so much love and joy and care put into so much of this game but it is perhaps, gameplay wise, the stingiest game like this I've ever played. The game is afraid to let the player have fun. The game will let you play for 40 minutes without cutting you any slack of the RNG before you realize the whole run was a hopeless waste of time. And it will do this a lot. Large stretches of the game become rote, yet if you try and casually go through them, your mistakes will have rippling effects into the later bit of the game. The game feels hard not because hard is fun, but hard because the developers were afraid of their game being too easy. It also doesn't help that so many of the items are boring and very situational and its super easy to get nothing but gag guns for entire runs. The characters are (outside their personality and very cooly stories and specialized ending bosses) really really boring. Of the starting classes, only Pilot is mechanically interesting, so changing classes doesn't give a reprieve from the monotony the is 'actually playing through the first half of the game'.

People like this game for a reason. The backhalf can be very fun and skill intensive in a way that doesn't feel punitive for the sake of being punitive. This, and the charm of the game surrounding the actual gungeoneering (the NPCs and goals and all that) makes me REALLY REALLY REALLY want to like it. And there is times I, for some glimmering moments, have a lot of fun. But where in Nuclear Throne, being screwed by the RNG is a small cost, in Gungeon it is a devestating waste of time. Enter the Gungeon is a game that revolves around the GUN. Banana gun, pea gun, gun gun, everything’s a gun! Combine this with references from a multitude of other games and media, and you get a charming, fun, but also challenging top-down shooter game.

The game starts out a bit easy, especially if this isn’t your first top-down shooter, but it quickly ramps up by the 2nd floor onwards, with more unpredictable enemies and dangerous environments. You will die, but with each death you learn a little more, and bit by bit you’ll figure out how to overcome all the obstacles that the Gungeon has to offer.

There are a wide variety of guns to uncover on your journey. You’ll come across and unlock more powerful, but also peculiar guns. Some are off of real-life guns, but the ones that will really grab your attention are the cool and badass-looking sci-fi ones; some of them are not as cool, and arguably even lame, but I think each gun has a charm in their own way. This flow of new guns to try out keeps your journey to The Gun keeps every run interesting. 

The pixel graphics are cute as hell; just look at the bullet kin! There is a great amount of attention paid to the details that you can’t help but appreciate. Great effort was also put into the text and dialogue, from Ammonomicon, to the various NPCs you can talk to, like the depressed alcoholic lizard. 

The soundtrack is stellar. It fills you with the motivation to explore the depths of the Gungeon and uncover its mysteries. The different musical tracks seamlessly blend into each other as you exit and enter new rooms, and can make a mix of the best parts of each track. At the end of every challenge in this game awaits an awesome tune to celebrate to.

The story element is kept light and brief, popping up only once in a while amidst the action, but it nonetheless contains some intriguing parts for you to discover and speculate on (or look up lol).

There is a 2-player co-op option, however, it’s local only. The co-op itself can be quite fun, and Remote Play on Steam bridges the physical gap with local co-op, but I’m still very disappointed to see this limitation in co-op.

One major complaint I have is the game’s lack of info on weapon synergies. Some of them you can figure out just from testing it out, but a lot are very obscure to the point where you’ll probably be unable to figure it out without looking it up on the wiki. This is something I don’t like to do because it often ruins the fun of learning and discovering on your first run.

In the grand scheme of things, the downsides aren’t too major. As someone who has enjoyed top-down shooters like Nuclear Throne, this game was extremely attractive to me, and it has shown itself to be one of the best that I’ve played. I loved its incredibly goofy style and the heart and soul put into it. Enter the Gungeon is a satisfying experience that any enjoyer of indie games must try out.

The game offers a great blend of humorous game design full of pop culture references,  simplistic and intuitive controls, various challenging enemies, a tremendous amount of different guns and items at the player's disposal and many floors of the Gungeon to explore, all of which are embedded in its charming, unique and creative pixelated artstyle.

The game's main weakness is that although the areas are procedurally generated, there is only a limited amount of enemies and rooms you can find within one single floor. As you might spend dozens of hours on each floor in total, this can almost get a little bland at times.

It's strenghts however are numerous. As there are only few core mechanics, each of them are very polished and well implemented. While the game can be quite difficult, the difficulty always felt fair. Each projectile that can damage you can also be dodged, there are no hidden tricks or enemies that require trial and error to defeat. Because of this, even though the game is so difficult, it never got very frustrating for me.

Considering the low price of the game, there is a lot of content for very cheap here, including several free DLC updates. I highly recommend the game to fans of the roguelike and bullet hell genres.

The gold standard for twin sticks, bullets hells, and rogue-lites. The guns and artifacts all interact with each other in an intuitive way. The enemies are varied and all have unique behaviors. The maps are well designed and while rooms are sometimes copied, the enemy pattern is often different and thus it always feels fresh. The bosses are tough but fair. The global progression is interesting and makes "bad" runs still feel fun, meaningful, and rewarding.

Each individual enemy, weapon, boss, room, item, and character makes the game continue to be fun even years after I purchased it. It's 15 bucks full price, but I would happily pay 60 for a game of this quality.

Enter The Gungeon is a celebration for the Rogue-Like genre. It’s variety and gameplay ​structure keeps me coming back to it every couple of months despite beating it ​dozens of times. This game uses the genre’s simple design of clearing rooms one after ​the other has been tweaked to make every playthrough so vastly different that I rarely ​even get the same weapon between attempts.

The art style of Enter The Gungeon is truly something to be desired by other indie ​games with the pixel art approach to aesthetics. Every room is immaculately ​decorated with such passion put into the animations of enemies and objects that it ​truly has a unique style which has defined it from similar game art like Celeste and ​Shovel Knight. When you shoot a bookcase pages go flying across the room, each ​enemy has it’s own unique animation for running shooting and dying, each gun ​(around 300 of them) have their own unique reloads and projectiles.

The main thing to be praised however is the sheer scale of their weapon variety and ​creativity to differentiate each one from the others. There’s a bullet gun that shoots ​pistols, a rocket launcher that shoots bees, there's a cardboard box that shoots buzz ​saws. Every weapon feels like it has it’s own playstyle behind it aswell, which makes ​the way the player approaches each attempt challenge different aspects of the ​gameplay. Sometimes you get weapons that are great to charge enemies down with ​like a shotgun, sometimes you have to duck behind propped up tables or nearby walls ​to take a calculated shot. Because weapons are found in chests it’s completely up to ​the player to balance the risk of investing in every chest, or waiting for especially rare ​ones, promoting a “risk it all to win big” approach to some levels.

The difficulty mainly comes from the aspect that if you die, you have to start all over ​again. My experience with perma-death before this game was hardcore World of ​Warcraft, or Baldur’s Gate honour mode and in both of these games a full playthrough ​is hundreds of hours, meaning every perma-death is usually a quit moment for the ​player. Enter The Gungeon streamlines the 90's approach to this by reducing the full ​playthrough to around 20 minutes of play. By doing this they can then crank up the ​difficulty to a ridiculous level in the hopes that the amount of progression made is so ​small, that people will repeatedly attempt to finish the game despite dying. They have ​essentially found a way to capitalise off the arcade game approach to player deaths ​within the modern age, and it makes for a game where I will often find myself trying ​once or twice every few months because of just how small of a time commitment it is.

Overall this game is a perfection of a rogue-like that we have never seen within the​ genre. The commendable amount of variety and fast paced gameplay has created a​ challenging but infinitely repeatable indie game that I will never tire of playing.​

WARNING This game is insanely punishing! That being said, game is addicting and fair. 

Tip: turn off the music and listen to your own playlist. No offence to the composer, and the title song is pretty cool, but it can get distracting when you're actually fighting. 

No run will be the same. There is a crazy variety of guns from a mailbox to a bubble gun to a bullet that shoots guns (yes, I wrote that correctly). Apart from the final floor, there are 3 different bosses you can potentially fight on each floor, so you don't fight the same bosses every time. 

I played 28 hours in my first two weeks, but right now I'm taking a break because I arguably played a bit much and it can be kinda demoralising at some point to keep dying and going back to the beginning. but there is a lot of metaprogression (unlocking more guns and items you can potentially get in each run), and I'm definitely gonna come back to it at some point. You just need to take a break every so often.

and now I will tell you how to make pancakes


[h3]INGREDIENTS[/h3]


-Milk 
-Eggs 4 pcs.
-Flour 500 g
-Oil 2 tbsp. l.
-Sugar 1.5 tbsp. l.
-Salt 0.5 tsp.

[h3]COOKING PROCESS[/h3]

Beat the eggs and sugar in a large bowl.
Heat some of the milk, add salt, and mix thoroughly with beaten eggs and sugar.
Gradually add flour to the resulting mixture, constantly stirring so that there are no lumps.
Add a little soda, salt and oil. Mix
Add the rest of the milk and beat. The dough should be moderately liquid.
Heat the pan.
Fry the pancake on both sides until golden.

وملاحظتي على هذا الكلام لأمرين:
١- أن الصعوبة ليست الهدف بحد ذاته في الكثير من الأحيان بل لوجود شيء يعطي معنى لهذه الصعوبة فالإنسان لا يأكل الطعام برجليه وهو غير محتاج لذلك بالرغم أن الأكل بالرجلين أصعب لكن ليس فيه فائدة ومثله الصعوبة في الألعاب فالمعنى مهم ورأيي أن الخطأ كان في تسهيل المهام الرئيسية إلى درجة أن الزعماء فقدوا هيبتهم وأصبحوا مثل حدائق الملاهي فهي جذابة للنظر وممتعة لكنها خاوية ولو رجعنا ورأينا ما الذي جعل أفضل قتلات للزعماء في تاريخ الألعاب سنجد أن واحد من أهم عناصرها هو أن الصعوبة متوازنة تجعلك تشعر بقوة الزعيم وهيبته فتتطرّ لتعلم حركاته وقدراته والتخطيط لهزيمته بدون الشعور باليأس هذا ما يجعل هؤلاء الزعماء أيقونيّن لذلك جعل الصعوبة فقط في المحتوى الجانبي يكون فراغ في قصة اللعبة من الصعب ملؤه.

READ THE FULL REVIEW (Steam has a word limit) HERE: https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/enter-the-gungeon---a-review
--
Simple review details - I rank games on an out of 10 basis, granting up to 3 points in 3 categories, as well as a last, single point from my own self, depending on my experience with it.

GAMEPLAY

Enter the Gungeon is a top-down roguelike, heavily inspired by the Binding of Isaac, which features the opporunity to select a Character and then descend into a procedurally generated dungeon filled with all kinds of threats. Over the course of a descent into the dungeon, the Player will find many guns with which to shoot at the varied Enemies, as well as a plethora of items that provide increases in power or intriguing effects.

The Player will also need to face down sublime bosses at the end of each level of the dungeon, with meticulously designed attack patterns and a clear incentive to partake in Trial-and-Error. However, one of the ways the game stands out from its competitors is its use of the dodge-roll, coupled with an emphasis on making the moment-to-moment gameplay, at least in combat, reminiscent of a Bullet Hell.

Dodge out of the way of countless projectiles, shoot the targets and secure victory, as well as potentially currency and a few usable items, so that the way to the final boss might open… Or is it the final boss? Aside from featuring a plethora of endings, based on each playable Character, Enter the Gungeon also features secret levels and additional gamemodes.

However, while all that is phenomenal, the game suffers from one thing – an overreliance on Random Number Generation (RNG), on luck, as well as a clear imbalance between the different weapons available to the Player. Some are very clearly just worse versions of others, and the bad versions are a lot more common than the good versions, which only leads into a lessening of the amount of fun that can be experienced by the Player.

Ultimately, the Gameplay’s smoothness is enough to nearly carry the game even in spite of its flaw, but by the time the Player gets good at dodging, they will start suffering from the RNG mechanics.

2/3

PRESENTATION

Enter the Gungeon is a phenomenal, in appearance, game. Powerful stylization, pixel-based graphics that have such unbelievable amounts of soul in them, a soundtrack that enchants the Player as though it were a fae in the woods, and animations so fluent and deliberate that it is astounding how some of them have come to be. 

3/3

STORY

In Enter the Gungeon, a group of hoodlums with various motivations have arrived at the Gungeon’s entrance and seek to enter, so as to find the gun that can kill time – or, rather, turn time back – because there’s something in their pasts that they need to set right.

Aside from that intriguing premise, there’s a plethora of colorful Characters and a bit of lore that can be unearthed through wandering about and discovering secrets, but that is as far as things go. There is a limited amount of story to be told, and there are even some slight inconsistencies that present themselves every now and then.

2/3

Legendary Point

Does this game get the legendary point, so craved and wanted by all and none at the same time?

 Considering everything stated by yours truly (me) so far, I have to inform you that the game does not obtain the legendary point. While it is true that I enjoyed it, greatly, it must be noted that much of my pleasure with this game came before I had truly come to know its intricacies, while the game was new and unknown to me, while I was still struggling to learn its ways. After I got decently good, I lost the joy I got from playing, as I would constantly find myself missing the keys or the items needed to make my runs through the Gungeon more pleasant. 0/1

CONCLUSION
7/10. Enter the Gungeon is not a bad game, at all. It is actually a very, VERY good game, if a bit too overwhelmingly praised by its players, though, when one considers what its competition is, one starts to see it in a different light. Alas, I review games based on themselves, and only themselves, thus EtG is just a very good game.

 I tuck it under my belt, another shining achievement that I proudly display. It could have glimmered even more brightly, but that will do.
--
READ THE FULL REVIEW (Steam has a word limit) HERE: https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/enter-the-gungeon---a-review

Fun game but a bit too rng heavy per run for my tastes, yes you can beat it with a starter pistol, but it's a slow and boring way of doing it. Sometimes you get more chests than keys, sometimes more keys than chests, sometimes complete dogshit guns, sometimes op guns, sometimes no health for ages when you have no hp, sometimes you get 2 hearts in a floor where you lost no health so they go to waste. Really boils down to grinding for a fun run from my perspective. Otherwise you're stuck with a shit weapon and it takes ages to clear rooms and bosses. Maybe you enjoy using a shit gun forever to chip away and your run taking 2* longer, I don't. There's a shitload of hidden unexplained game mechanics so have fun reading the wiki almost as much as you're playing the game.

Core gameplay is simple but solid, I just wish that run to run was more consistent like e.g. Hades.

After all the abuse faced at the hands of this game, and uninstalling it a second time, I really don't feel like typing out my usual, long-form, article-type review, so here's literally every issue I found with the game in a nicely-organised, bulleted (pun not intended) list (with the possibility of expanding it to a usual-styled typing in the future):

- It's unfairly, punishingly difficult

- Certain bullet patterns seem like they're designed to cause you to get hit, unlike Danmaku where you can weave your way through everything.

- Dodge Roll has way too little bay way of Invincibility Frames, ensuring you'll leap over one wave of bullets, then get hit by something that was unavoidably spat out behind.

- Good luck dodging anything from the side in an isometric game.

- No guarantee exists that you'll be given a key to get a gun beyond your standard starting one, and other times you'll watch as a gun chest is detonated in front of you, because the game only gave you a single key to open the gate before the locked chest with.

- Only one of the guns I got I enjoyed in the slightest, and I picked up over 10 of the things.

- Dark Souls II Design Philosophy of “just throw more stuff at them; somebdoy'll do it!”

- None of the items I got felt like they ever did literally anything, much less upgraded the character in any form or fashion, far less actually improved survivability in any way.

- For the amount of bullets they vomit out, seemingly without any actual effort put into making sure they can be avoided, bosses take wayy too long to kill.

- Rooms can sometimes spawn more enemies after the first wave is clear, but only sometimes

- ...and no visual indication exists to show a second wave will spawn after the first.

- To make matters worse, they also don't design the room around the enemies, rather just throw things in there and hope you'll get out of it.

- As such, spending wayyyyy too bloody long in a room clearing it with the default weapon as a result of you not being able to get anything else starts to wear incredibly quickly.

- Even with the teleporters, it takes an inordinate amount of time to get to the next room that you've not cleared out yet, to the point even my easily-amused Autistic brain chose twice to quit to desktop than wander all the way back to a room that will be a boring, unengaging, samey slog to clear out, only for more things to spawn in and artificially extend play time.

Verdict: Not recommended from someone who tortured themselves long enough to platinum the Binding of Isaac: Repentance.

I honestly try to like this game, but in all seriousness, it's just way, WAY too brutal for my liking. I love the pixel art, flashy animations, sound design, etc. Devolver's games have always been my favorite, but Enter the Gungeon will beat you senseless until you don't want to play anymore. It's so full of charm, but it's all just completely overshadowed by the game's ludicrous difficulty.
Yes, I know, 4.2 hours isn't enough to come to such a consensus. It could also be that I'm just awful at the game, and you know what, that's probably part of the problem. It's likely a skill issue on my part, but still. This game will make sure you die 600 times before even defeating the first boss. Out of all the runs I must've played so far, I only got to the second floor once before dying to a slime.
Sometimes, it doesn't even feel like the character you pick matters that much. The Marine does have an extra hit point, but that's only if you don't get hit before the first boss room, because at that point, you may as well restart the entire run. The Convict's damage boost after she gets hit doesn't feel usable at all. No matter what, you're only going to get to the second floor a few times within the first 10 hours of gameplay.

Enter the Gungeon is a fantastic game. 

The gameplay is intuitive and extremely fun. Tons of replayability where at lest 95% of your runs will will be different then one another. A lot of secrets and unlockables to find and complete. A bunch of challenge and fun game modes if the standard game is getting stale. All the while the game definitely has pretty decent difficulty to it, but can be conquered with memorization, game skill and some RNG with guns and items.

Highly recommend to fans and newer players of the bullet hell/twin stick shooter genre.

One of my favorite roguelikes.  It doesn't hold your hand and there is little in the way of meta progression, but the controls are so tight and bosses so well designed that it feels good to 'learn' the game.  I went from eating dirt on the second and third floor all the time to consistently beating the game most runs with any character. 

99% of my time was spent in single player.  I didn't care for multiplayer because of the bullet hell nature of the game - an extra person just makes the screen more chaotic.

My only complaint is that it has a roguelite feature you find in a lot of others in the genre where your main source of unlocks are just new items in the pool.  Most of these are better than the initial weapons/items available but it sucks you sometimes have to dilute the pool with crap to gain access to some of the better stuff.
Very fast paced and funny.  10/10 would gun again.

I personally would not recommend buying this game at all, suggesting you get Nuclear Throne or The Binding of Isaac instead

The game is exceedingly slow, with you spending forever to beat each room and traversing the map itself being slow. The bosses are damage sponges that take what feels like an eternity to kill, even the death animation (in a roguelike where you are expected to die often) is far too slow and makes trying to start a new run feel less fluid and natural. The guns all feel like they're firing wet balls of paper, with tiny bullets that chip away at enemy health and are hard to use from the range the game clearly wants you to fight at given the utterly absurd number of projectiles every enemy in the game shoots. It is especially noticeable with the bosses who take several times as long as they should to kill and who all seem to be more fitting to a late game area rather than the very beginning.
The game's item system is also unbalanced as it is entirely possible to not find a gun on the first floor, in a game about guns and shooting them, which leaves you with the pathetically weak default weapons for the needlessly strong bosses
The artstyle is alright and the ability to save health for later is a very welcome one but I feel that the slow, awkward and spammy gameplay is by no means worth the occasional interesting idea
Nuclear Throne is a much more fun top down, gun based shooter with actual ammo management, fast and fun gameplay, bosses who are strong but don't overstay their welcome, far more interesting character design and unique playable characters with their own strong upsides, etc. I have tried to play this game but cannot find the passion or motivation to keep going, while Nuclear Throne was an immediate favourite game.

I hope this was helpful if you're debating whether or not to get the game and I have no ill will towards the developers themselves. Also apologies if it is a bit rant-y and disorganised, I am not the best at writing

Enter the Gungeon is one of the few good Top-Down Bullet Hell Twin-Stick Shooters. Because honestly, there aren't even that many. But quality wise, it's right down there with Nuclear Throne and the Binding of Isaac. The gameplay is more complex than Nuclear Throne, and that could be good or bad depending on what you want. The game is hard, punishing hard. But not as hard as Nuclear Throne. Each map has pre-generated rooms of layouts, and this is where the combat happens. So it's easier and you don't get spammed. There are a lot of guns, but not every gun is good unlike, again, Nuclear Throne.

But one thing to say about Gungeon is that the it oozes style. The jams and atmosphere are finely crafted.

I've played this game to absolute completion. Due to the procedural nature and the very high skill-ceiling of the game, you really can get 300+ hours of gameplay out of it. If you enjoy bullet hells or the roguelike genre, I could not recommend a game more than this one.

Since I've played it so much I've probably forgotten how difficult it is for a beginner. However, if you're feeling defeated or frustrating by the game - my advice is to take a mental reset and come back again. Even after you "beat" the game for the first time, there's several more tiers of completion to REALLY beat the game, and I promise it's worth grinding out the skill required to conquer the gungeon. It is a masterpiece of the modern bullet hell genre.

Enter the Gungeon is a roguelike following four adventurers into the biggest collection of weapons and gun-based puns of the whole galaxy, surrounded by a dark dungeon which hides an ancient artifact meant to kill the past.

For me, it’s an obvious recommended, but I’m going first through its bad aspects.

I’ve personally met people that didn’t like this game. One of them an old friend from uni, another one myself, way down in the past. And the problem was the same for both of them/us: the difficulty.

Now, given that this is a game that I truly love (or learned to love), I think I have a ground to say that for NO GAME being difficult is a virtue. For me being difficult it’s just like the genre, some people like one or another, you shouldn’t hold against them that they don’t like your favourite genre, nor your favourite method of torture. And “git gut” is no an argument to make a game more appealing.

Because where some see difficulty, I see in this game a rather bad accessibility. This game is definitely, particularly odd with its learning curve. I’ve played a demo (ehem) back when it was freshly published, almost 7 years ago. And almost every year I would… Rent it… To play it again and again. And out of the five floors of the dungeon, I’ve BARELY made it to the fifth one in all those years, and only two months ago I managed to kill the final boss.

And you know what happened after that? Now there is no run where I don’t get to the fourth floor and I finished the game with every character in three days.

And it feels strange. The thing is, back then, I remember it vividly. It FELT impossible. I hate reading guides and letting people on forums and crap tell me which items are best and builds and such… And I almost felt like unless they held my hand, I was never gonna be able to even smell the finale.

From which I get the feel that, anyone that’d try the game could feel the same. And although I ended up loving this game, I can see some people not liking it because of how the experience is in the beginning.

And the thing is, there doesn’t seem to be an option to customize your experience besides cheating. Which is a bit sad, given that I believe that people used to a more casual experience are actually missing the great things in the game.

Which is another bad point for me. You get to choose between characters, which have pretty dynamic and interesting abilities that tell them apart, but that’s about it. Down the line, as you advance, the runs tend to equalize them. Their own abilities die down and are functionally replaced by what is found in the dungeon. Moreover, it felt like this game could really use an “infinite” or “arsenal” mode to experiment more with the equipment. Builds feels great, but you know that, as you approach the end (which past certain points becomes as I said a bit too easy to reach), you are going to say goodbye forever to them. 

And yeah, it’s a roguelike… But it’s not helped by the fact that the floors you go through are pre-selected and the same (at least for all the runs I’ve gone through). They are procedural, of course, but you expect the same combination of enemies and bosses for every floor, which tends to streamline the experience (feeding into that weird difficulty vibe) and again screams for a bit of a “freer” experience besides the core one.

With all of this tho… I’ve already mentioned that I didn’t like the game… But I kept coming, always coming to be cursed by the past…

This game, in little dosages, is really, really fun. And in many ways.

When you are starting or have a bad run, the enemies are out there for your blood. Fights are chaotic and frenetic, just quick enough to not give you any breather, but fair enough to make you feel your own mistakes. The bosses are quite dynamic, you feel their power. But they also give you down time to put some bullets into them.

The guns, save a bunch of life-mirroring ones… Are, of course, the best part. So many types of damage, shooting patterns, synergies and strange gimmicks with added effects: Seeking bullets, bouncing bullets, exploding bullets, bullets that clear other bullets, arrow-shaped wooden bullets, shotguns shooting guns that shoot bullets… Planet bullets (for some reason).

And yes, if you like stupid dad-grade humour, you’ll definitely find many parts in this game amusing or even hilarious.

The enemies are ridiculous, the bosses are ridiculous, the guns themselves are clearly ridiculous. So many bullet and guns puns… This game feels like a parody of some sort or some kind of long-drawn joke that someone got into too deep.

And there is a lot of content. Enemies aren’t that numerous, and after you beat it for the first time, you probably would have seen almost all of them (given again, that the roster for each floor is fixed). But there are a huge number of guns, so much that even to this day I’m not sure I’ve seen all of them and I still keep getting surprised.

The items, on the other hand, are a bit meh in my opinion. You can only carry one or two active items at a time, they require to deal damage to recharge every time you use them (obviously in the name of balance) and, ultimately, I find myself giving them a pass.

The passive ones are more interesting, as they are a big part of the synergy at play with the guns, enabling stuff like active reloads, piercing, poisoning and other effects… Or doing something a bit simpler like increasing your health pool. But beyond that, they may affect specific weapons to enable very specific gimmicks for them, which is quite interesting.

Also, once you overcome the tragic learning curve, skill has more weight than in some other roguelikes. At least, this is true for common enemies; eventually you can with most fights with well-timed dodging and even taking advantage of the room’s hazards. Bosses are a bit of another story. Having poor firepower can put you quickly on the stop, sometimes beyond what you can do, unless you’ve got an extensive practice against a specific boss.

No matter what, slowly (quite slowly mind you), you unlock new and powerful weapons to be found with the credits awarded from killing the bosses, which gives some sense of progression. There are also characters around the dungeon that you unlock to join the main hub so they can be found during your runs.

While there are certainly a couple of funny and interesting characters, gameplay-wise they don’t feel like a very important addition. They appear so rarely that you barely notice their presence, and most of the time they don’t really impact your run. Even the store that you find every floor is quite the hit or miss. It feels more like the only reliable place to get health, blanks (which help you by cleaning a room from bullets for a short time) and keys, than a place to invest your hard-earned money for some new guns.

To conclude, this is in general a really good game, when played with moderation. If you are going to buy it and aren’t used to usual roguelike and bullet-hell bs, you should be ready to be frustrated, many many times, before getting a hand of it. Otherwise, you may be condemned to throw it at the back of your library and never play it again. But, if you vibe with it, it’s one of the funniest casual experiences you can have. Lock and load!

Mostly I have 1 important thing to say, and I'll get to that in a second. First, I just want to point out that this game is really well made, and super fun, and I'm kinda bad at bullet hell, so just know that none of my critique is based on the fact that I'm bad at it. 

What I want to say is this: Gungeon is pretty far-off from something like Binding of Isaac in terms of the item synergy mechanics at the core of its roguelite gameplay. That confusing sentence is not a quality assessment, just an observation. In my limited time I've found that Gungeon does not supply you with infinitely compounding item effects during each run, but rather, a pretty tight load-out that you assemble from random items, and the shops, that consists of a few powerful weapons, and a few discrete (often non-synergistic) powerups/relics that assist your damage output but don't greatly change the way you play. 

It's a subtle difference. So subtle you might just think I'm out to lunch, but I find it very noticeable. I came to this from games like Isaac and Slay the Spire, and was disappointed in the lack of emphasis on compiling wacky synergies. That is absolutely a, "to each their own," situation, and I don't hold it against Gungeon that it does things differently, but it isn't quite what I, personally, look for in a roguelite.
