King of its genre. At least if you want a skill-based game and not a power-fantasy game like binding of isaac.

It is very rare to become brokenly powerful in this. It's hard but fair, and pretty much never gives you the ability to completely cheese it without playing well. I can tell the devs wanted the game to feel fair, and made sure the value of skill majorly outweighs the value of luck. This is rare for the genre. If you want to be unstoppable and mindlessly blast every room with a million exploding bullets like in Isaac, you're not really gonna get that. You're going to have to play well or lose. FYI the reviews saying this game is all RNG are just crap at the game. This is the least luck-based roguelike I've ever played.

There isn't meta progression in the sense that you get permanent upgrades, but you do unlock items/guns that you can find on future runs which are generally better than the starting stuff. There is other progression such as unlocking npcs that can unlock more items or put special effects on your runs, and some character unlocks.

The gunplay and boss fights are what makes this game so good. Pretty much every fight is satisfying as you dodge around tons of stuff, which actually have good choreography and don't diarrhea all over the screen in a way that's unreadable. Again this game is hard but fair, and you will pretty much never be BS-ed into taking damage. It's pretty much completely your fault.

I like almost everything about this game. But ok, there are a couple annoyances.
- Many guns need the button spammed to shoot at max speed. Ever since contra 1 this has been a plague. It's annoying, tiresome, and is going to take years off the health of our hands, especially avid gamers. Please stop.
- Items don't give enough information so if you really want to make the best decisions and play right, unfortunately you're gonna have to look every item up. Again please stop.
- Hp is very limited which is good. The only way to increase max hp is beating bosses without getting hit. This makes things tense, but, the fact it's all-or-nothing to snowball to a victory is very annoying. Maybe a single hit taken could give half as much of an increase? No-hit reward system is a good idea but it's too strict and binary.

Ah, Enter the Gungeon - a game that has become a beacon of joy in my life, especially during this unique chapter I find myself in. As a 50-year-old man navigating the winding roads of life post-divorce, Enter the Gungeon has been a welcome escape and an unexpected source of comfort.

You know, life can throw curveballs at any age, and for me, this game has been a delightful distraction, a chance to dive into a world filled with whimsy and challenge. And amidst all the chaos, the Bullet Kin, that charming little bullet-shaped character, has become my favorite companion in the Gungeon.

There's something oddly comforting about their determined little faces as they bravely face the onslaught of bullets and chaos. Maybe it's a reflection of my own journey, finding the courage to face challenges head-on and come out stronger on the other side.

Enter the Gungeon's gameplay, with its ever-changing layouts and vast array of weapons, has become a metaphor for life's unpredictability. Each run through the Gungeon is a fresh adventure, reminding me that no matter how tough things get, there's always a chance for a new beginning, a new discovery, and maybe even a treasure or two along the way.

The witty humor and clever design of this game have provided me with laughter and a sense of wonder, reminding me that age is just a number. In a way, my midlife crisis has led me to this gem of a game, showing me that it's never too late to find joy in unexpected places.

So, if you're like me, navigating the complexities of life and looking for a little escape, I wholeheartedly recommend Enter the Gungeon. It might just become your sanctuary, a place where you can find solace, excitement, and a newfound appreciation for the simple joys in life.

This game is unreasonably bullshit the majority of the time, whether it be in your favor or against your favor, usually against you. On top of that there's just so much little shit in this game that just builds and builds one after another that just makes it so damn tedious and annoying to play through each time, so let me run through a few shall I?


The first issue i have with this game is the item descriptions or lack thereof, not that the game doesn't have them, but it's that it suffers from the fact that most of the fucking item descriptions don't actually tell you what the item you just picked up does, it just gives you some random useless bit of story or a stupid joke which don't help you at all you just have to fuck around until you figure out what it does, and even then good luck because a lot of the time the only point when you would be able to use it you would never fucking think to use it there, but either way good luck even making it to a point where you would get to use it since most of the time the average casual player wont be able to get through the first damn level and past the first boss because most of them just throw legions of shit at you with barely any space to dodge, even if you try to dodge through the rounds more often than not you just end up dodging into more bullets and take damage anyway. And another thing I hate about the bosses is as far as i know there's no way to skip the intro for them so you're forced to sit there for like a solid 10 seconds for it to do it's intro animation every single time and then spend another solid 5 or 6 second death animation of the clock showing up which you also can't skip, when you're first starting in the game hey sure it isn't the absolute worst thing, but after about the 12th damn time it gets irritating at best. Another thing that gets on my nerves is that despite the fact that there are 4 different characters to pick from none of them have significant enough changes from each other to actually make you want to pick one over the other except for the Marine who has one extra temporary armor point a weapon with the highest starting ammo count for his starter weapon as well as fire rate (at least as far as i can tell) and has an ability to call in more ammo for other weapons, so you have pretty much no reason to pick anyone else since the rest have shit like a weak AOE special and two junk weapons, a dog and a slow garbage revolver, or a small chance to either unlock a chest for free or make it inaccessible for good with a stupidly inaccurate slow firing laser pistol. All of these things combined just makes me want to lobotomize myself with an ice-pick after just a couple of runs.

I want to say that it's just a legit skill issue on my end because i like rouge-likes other games like this like the binding of Isaac and would really like to say i enjoy this one too, but i just can't say i do in honesty, there are just so many small things that build up and up throughout the game that just ruins it for me, if you have the patience for this sort of stuff and have the time to waste as well as the money to just throw out, go ahead and get it, but i really would suggest you just go play the binding of Isaac instead.

I still play this game a bit when I'm doing certain things since it pretty mindless and repeatable but no matter how hard I try I just can't recommend it. After just 1 or 2 runs it becomes extremely boring. playing with a friend requires a 3rd party application. The main issue I have is the overall mechanics such as the dodge. I have found that using the dodge as little as possible is the best option since after the recover your vulnerable for what feels like an eternity and if you dodge in the wrong direction, such as in the same direction of a bullet you will 100% get hit cause you move at the same speed as most bullets. So while it is fun it becomes not fun very quickly.

If you're into very difficult games then you might like it more but for a rogue-lite it just seems a little too punishing for my taste. Especially when its the mechanic thats supposed to get you out of trouble that seems to screw you over the most. If you want to sit here and practice this game to get good, you totally can but I find myself getting bored way too soon for me to want to get better at it. Also the RNG doesn't feel rewarding at all. I can sometimes get almost to the boss of the second dungeon and have received very little loot at all, which is ridiculous for a rogue-lite. I originally planned on giving it a recommend but as I kept writing this review I realized that I just couldn't. This is one of the worst rogue-lites I have played in a long time. Also there is "synergy" with items but its basically pointless since the odds of you getting those items together is tiny. I genuinely don't understand why this game is as popular as it is.
I need bigger weapon.

EtG is a big game, like ridiculously big, most people will only experience 1/4 of the levels in the game at all, and the fact that there are more than twice the amount of hidden levels (outside of the main floors) than the main floors isn't helping that lol. I am still regularly seeing new content just from how the devs made unlocks happen. I do think the game can be a bit unforgiving when you are learning, mostly because the game doesn't give you many tips or hints at all, pretty much everything is on you to either figure out or look up. I think many more people would have gotten much further in this game if the tutorial had included more than the bare minimum practice required to play. That being said, if you do decide to take the plunge and really learn the game then you will experience one of the most challenging and rewarding "BS hard games" out there. I would wholeheartedly recommend EtG if you are looking for a dungeon crawler that is super satisfying to learn and master.

All that being said, here are some mostly spoiler free tips that I wish the devs hinted at in the tutorial:
1. Master the early floors - without getting into too much detail, doing good and taking no damage early will reward you even more and make the end game substantially easier. The other benefit to not taking damage early is that you will have many more shells later to buy ammo, guns, or items since you will not need to buy healing.
2. Synergies - some items, passives, and guns will totally change the way some other items or guns work in wild and powerful ways. Some of the synergies are super strong and very much worth it, and because they are such a huge game changer (literally) I really wish there was a catalog in game or some way of seeing which items would synergize with your kit before actually going and buying/getting that item since what items you buy can make or break the run, but since there isnt, the wiki is the next best place to learn about these.
3. On that topic... you can steal things! Very helpful if there is a very expensive item you want to test drive. or synergy you want. As to how to steal things, without getting into too much detail, anything that makes you invisible/takes targeting off of you is a good place to start ; ) 
4. More Characters to play as! - At ~150 hours, I still do not have all of them, but I am close. The game does not really give you any indication that there even ARE hidden characters, let alone how to get them so I would recommend looking at the wiki to see how to unlock them. They are VERY worth it, super fun and genuinely play different than the starting characters, which adds much needed variety after you have a ton of time in the game.

I don't consider it to be a bad game per se, but after finishing it I can say that it is a game in which you depend a lot on rng, way more than games like hades or isac to win, so much that I don't recommend buying it, in fact That's probably why so few people finish it.
The only thing you can do if you are moderately skilled to increase your chances of winning is to try to beat the bosses without receiving any hits, they reward you with important buffs, but if you don't manage to do it, no matter how much you know how to dodge, if you don't get anything good, like important weapon interaction or at least some decent passive skills, winning would be almost impossible, the bosses have an absurd amount of life as you advance and they throw a lot of bullets in all directions, if you have nothing to destroy or repulse projectiles In some way, you will hardly last long, it is a very frustrating game because the difficulty lies only in that, the rng, the absurd number of enemies per room and the projectiles they launch, not because they have mechanics that are difficult to learn or something like that. In fact the final boss is easier than the 4th level bosses, thats crazy, it is entertaining but very unbalanced, in the end all the hours it takes you to spend its because you are gaining more powerful weapons and objects that increase your chance in long term of getting a good weapon or object, not for anything else like idk, unlock the possibility of selecting a weapon or maybe an object when advancing from chamber to chamber or something like a typical rogue like that works well.

TL;DR Great game, worth the price, some frustrating mechanics and achievements, not much story but some lore, overall 8/10 


I don't know what else I can say that someone else hasn't already said about this game but I guess I can give you the perspective of someone who has finished the game multiple times with each character and obtained every achievement. 

Your very first run will likely go something like this:
>clear the first rooms 
>get some neat guns
>fight the first boss
>die on the second floor

And the second run will likely go similar to that, but each time you will get just a little bit better. That's where the fun in this game comes from. Learning just a little bit more about this weird Gungeon that you're exploring every time you attempt another go at it. It takes some time to get good at, but the closer you get to the end, the more you will want to keep playing.

My best memory playing this game has to be making it all the way to the final boss, only to die just before I was able to beat him... And then finding out one of the items I had revived me with full hearts and let me absolutely decimate the last bit of health the boss had left. 

Moments like this are what make Enter the Gungeon so much fun. You won't know how exactly any given run will go! That being said it can also be very frustrating to be at the end of a challenge run only to get screwed by something you could not plan for or "get good" at. 

Some of the achievements are incredibly frustrating to get for this reason as well because they require certain enemies or drops to appear, and the only way for this to happen is to just get lucky. The story is also pretty simple and there is some lore to discover but most things just boil down to reference or pun. 

Overall I still enjoyed the game enough to play it to compilation and I would recommend you at least play enough to beat the game with the 4 starting characters. The price is very fair for the amount of time you will likely get out of this so don't worry about if you should wait for it to go on sale or not before buying if you really want to play it right now.

At $15, Enter the Gungeon is more than worth it's price.  While the game is tough and demanding, it also perfectly demonstrates that practice does indeed make perfect.  This isn't to say that the game is inaccessible to newcomers.  The game eases you deeper and deeper into the gungeon over time.  It reveals new characters, new mechanics, hidden characters, hidden bosses, etc.  These systems work well to not over-complicate the game and even give the player some form of awareness over what their next gungeon run might have in store.  Some things are hidden initially, but most things in the game will eventually reveal themselves organically to the player, save for a few exceptions that definitely are aided by guides.

Overall, the game is a 10/10.  The gameplay is tight, the art design is super charming, and the game is rewarding and remains rewarding over a long time.  If you need a new game to get, make it this one.

Enter The Gungeon is a fantastic rogue-like that I've enjoyed enough to purchase it on both my Switch and PC. There's something viscerally enjoyable about playing this game and unlocking the plethora of content hidden within, from additional levels, characters, game modes and of course, the vast array of guns and items that you can get a hold of. The sheer amount of variety available with builds make each run feel unique. Maybe you got on Lady Luck's good side and you got one good weapon after another, letting you plow through the goofy variety of enemies inhabiting the Gungeon. Or maybe, you got nothing but weak rolls and useless items that force you to get smart with how you play and make you a better player. I've enjoyed this game immensely and would absolutely recommend it to any fan of the rogue-like genre.

This Game is stupidly hard sometimes and the control scheme throws me off no matter how many times i change it to help fit my play style. the whole thing revolves around dodging any and every attack while also being able to aim at the enemy with weapons that shoot differently and in every direction known and unknown to man. maybe im just stupid but i find it stupidly impossible to multitask in this game somehow so i never got farther than the second boss no matter how many runs i went through.

An amazing game that kick started my love for the roguelike/dungeon crawler genre. As with every game in this genre, RNG plays a very big role in deciding your run but you do have a couple choices throughout that can help you shape it in a certain direction. I wasn't the biggest fan of some of the more vague unlocks (like unlocking the bullet or the paradox) but ultimately I just looked up guides on how to best go about doing it. It is a shame that I first played this game on the Epic launcher since thats about 200 hours lost to time, but at least it worked enough to carry over majority of my achievements. Overall I think this game is amazing, and although I know most people credit Isaac with being the father of modern roguelikes, this game will be the one that made me fall in love with the genre.

It's my second time playing this game, sunk around 400 hours into it on ps4 and am working on platinum on pc. This thing will swallow your life if you let it, and that's a good thing. Especially with all of the variability in recent years with the synergies/combo items. 
You'll die a lot, over and over again, as you're getting used to the near bullet hell of it's bosses, but you'll adapt.

Ammoconda should've been a third floor boss though it's uncanny how hard it is compared to the other floor two bosses. I can no-hit the other two reliably on a bad day, but Ammoconda can cripple me on a good one.

I owned this game for such a long time... at first it just scratched an itch every once in awhile for a quick rogue like game to kill some time with. I ended up getting in this loop where I would feel like playing this game, to then uninstalling the next day. I never really took the time to really dive in.

Well, lets just say the past month or so, I actually did manage to dive in. You may think this simple rogue like game is all about shooting fun guns and killing bosses, but that is just the surface. The developers did such an amazing job throwing you into the gungeon and just letting you experience the game. The secrets and different ways to play is immense for what feels like a straightforward game. I'm about 100 hours in, have yet to unlock every item in the game, and there are STILL things I have yet to do. And the beautiful thing of it all is that the game doesn't give you any hints, you are left to your own devices when it comes to exploring the gungeon.

Totally recommend this game.

Enter the Gungeon is a fantastic addition to the roguelike and bullet hell genres, offering a unique blend of challenging gameplay, humor, and an impressive variety of weapons and items. Developed by Dodge Roll and published by Devolver Digital, this game stands out for its innovative design and addictive gameplay.

Pros:

Challenging Gameplay: "Enter the Gungeon" provides a high level of difficulty, requiring players to master dodging and weaving through intricate bullet patterns. Each playthrough offers a fresh challenge, making it highly replayable.

Weapon Variety: One of the game's standout features is its vast array of imaginative weapons, ranging from standard firearms to bizarre and comical armaments. Experimenting with different weapons keeps the gameplay fresh and exciting.

Co-op Mode: The game supports local co-op, allowing you to team up with a friend for some intense, chaotic fun. Cooperation and communication are essential for success, adding to the game's replayability.

Humor and Style: "Enter the Gungeon" features a quirky sense of humor and charming pixel art style that adds personality to the game. The diverse cast of characters and the absurdity of their quest to find a legendary gun create an engaging atmosphere.

Randomization: Each playthrough is procedurally generated, meaning you'll never experience the same dungeon layout twice. This randomness adds unpredictability and keeps the game from becoming repetitive.

Cons:

Steep Learning Curve: The game can be quite challenging, and the learning curve may be steep for newcomers to bullet hell shooters or roguelikes. Some players may find it frustrating at first.

Permadeath: Like many roguelikes, "Enter the Gungeon" has a permadeath mechanic. Some players may be discouraged by the loss of progress upon death.

Repetitiveness: While the procedural generation helps keep things fresh, some players might still find the gameplay repetitive after numerous runs.

In conclusion, "Enter the Gungeon" is an excellent game for fans of challenging roguelikes and bullet hell shooters. Its unique weapons, humor, and co-op mode make it an enjoyable experience for those willing to tackle its difficulty. However, if you're not a fan of challenging gameplay or permadeath mechanics, it may not be the right choice for you.

Be prepared to have 3 tabs open (Weapons, items, and Shrines) because you will need them. You will be swapping back and forth probably hundreds of times.

There is a fuck ton of guns, fuck ton of items, a mega super fuck ton of synergies. 

Everything is guns, and everything seems to be references to movies, shows, pop culture, and most importantly, other video games. and its done so it such a cute and vibrant pixel style. 

A good selection of characters with different abilities and back stories (and their own boss) a pretty fair progression system. The NPCs are entertaining and numerous, the bosses are numerous and unique. Having 1 or 3 different bosses for each level adds on to the already massive replay-ability of this game.

I was looking for something along the lines of The Binding of Isaac Afterbirth. I'd heard good things about Enter the Gungeon so I thought I'd give it a try. Unlike BoI, the ramp up in difficulty is less a slope more like a cliff face. If the early bosses where a bit easier and the drops more frequent, I'd probably enjoy the game. As it is, the first bosses are brutally difficult and the drops are pathetically inadequate. It would be fine if the enemies prepared you more for the bosses but they don't in any meaningful way, and that's just bad game design. Difficulty for the sake of difficulty is also bad design. I bought it on sale and I recommend you buy it on sale, but only if you like to be punished. Personally, I don't find this kind of thing fun.

I've been waiting for write this review for about 2 years now. Me and a bunch of friends got this game free on epic a long time ago. I have 207 hours there, but the game was so good I felt the need to get it on steam (on sale) just to be able to get achievements/write a review/actually pay for such a good game. This is one of my top 10 games.

This is one of the most fun combat systems I've seen in any game with a bunch random little things you can do in this game, and it's art style is incredible. Almost every gun has some sort of cool ability or unique way of working, everything is some kind of reference to something else, and every thing in this game is some kind of joke (or a bullet). Gungeon is like a cheeky love letter to video games.

The progression in this Gungeon is so satisfying (at first), you always have some sort of goal or something to find/do in the Gungeon, always another reason to do another run always something too look out for, I love the way unlocking new items works, either through completing some sort of task, or spending the credits you get from bosses. Though once you near the end game of completing that damn ammonomocon... the progression just feels tiring and boring. Especially the hunts you have to do, it was a fun side thing to look out for at first but when you have to do runs specifically to floor 3 just to hope you get a single shambling round out of 20... yea the game just wasn't fun anymore.

There are about 60 enemies in the game, all pretty unique and really fun to fight, and about 30 bosses, that are (mostly) all fun to learn. and get down, the combat is super high energy and just the right level of difficulty. The incentive to always do bosses hit-less makes it never feel like at least the bosses never go stale.

Something I really appreciate is that unlike some rogue likes (((Isaac))) the game is always fun right off the bat. Runs arent boring or agonizing to start because the combat and enemy design is well done. Items are fun, but they aren't what make the game.

A big issue I take with the game, is it's clarity towards the player. This game has secret floors they never hit and and have INCREDIBLY arbitrary ways of getting to them, and hidden mechanics that they never tutorialize (coolness, curse, stealing). Also there are in game item descriptions, but they aren't really accurate. Most items only have some of what they do in there description, and a couple of them just have joke descriptions so you constantly need a wiki open for this game to know what you're even picking up. 
I will admit, exchanging information constantly with my friends where we all constantly asked "what does this do, how does this work" as we were all exploring the Gungeon early on, was a fun experience to have, and maybe more fun for me that way, but single player games shouldn't need that. 

This was my first rogue-like, and I used to think it was perfect since I hadn't played others. After playing about 40 hours of the Binding of Isaac, it's both given me more of an appreciation for this game, and it opened my eyes to realize this games just... too repetitive after a while. Don't get me wrong, they did a banger job, still got 200 hours out of it and had a ton of fun, though the further I got into progression the less fun the game felt. But there's not as much complexity to your build due to the fact there there's less item management as there could be with things like Isaac's consumables or trinkets. There aren't very many bullet effects, theres little to no interaction you have with the way you get items, most of the games variety comes from it's guns, and those get stale after a while. Every run usually comes down too "Okay heres my boss clearing gun, heres my room clearing gun." The inclusion of the rat stealing your items/pickups when you leave them in a room just makes the game anti item management. I thought it was for balance at first but I cant for the life of me think of how it balances the game, just makes it less fun.

The Boss DPS cap is kinda stupid and makes being overpowered not as fun as it should be, just drags out bosses when you have literally no chance of dying.

"Enter the Gungeon" is a fast-paced shooter developed by Dodge Roll and published by Devolver Digital. The game follows a group of brave characters as they enter a dangerous underground labyrinth called the Gungeon and battle enemies while searching for a valuable object. Filled with a variety of weapons, abilities and challenging enemies, this fun world offers players the opportunity to test their quick reflexes and strategy skills.

Unique Weapon Variety: One of the most remarkable aspects of the game is the vast and unique weapon collection. Each weapon has its own unique gameplay style and characteristics. The variety of weapons ensures that the game offers a different experience every time.

Challenging Enemies and Boss Battles: Players encounter a variety of enemies and particularly challenging boss battles throughout the maze. These battles test players' ability to react quickly and use strategy.

Randomly Generated World: The game offers randomly generated levels and enemy arrangements. This ensures a different experience each time the game is played and increases replayability.

Co-operative Playability: "Enter the Gungeon" offers two-player co-operative gameplay. Players can co-operate with friends and fight together against enemies and bosses.

Secret Rooms and Progress: The game is full of hidden rooms, secrets and special items. There is a lot of hidden content for players to discover throughout the game.

However, the game's high difficulty level may be off-putting for some players. Initially, it may take some time to get used to the game's difficulty and gameplay mechanics.

Overall, "Enter the Gungeon" offers a fun and addictive experience for players who enjoy fast-paced shooters. The variety of weapons, randomly generated world, and challenging enemies keep players' attention and skills firmly gripped. If you like games based on quick reaction and strategy, "Enter the Gungeon" can offer you hours of enjoyment.

Maybe it's the good ol' "skill issue" that's preventing me from enjoying the game, but I [i]really[/i] didn't enjoy this game. While I've played and enjoyed my fair share of rogue-likes (Darkest Dungeon, FTL, Inscryption, and Hades, to name a few), and their sharp spikes in difficulty at times, I just did not have fun with Enter the Gungeon at any time, and I can chalk it up to a few key grievances I have with the game design: 
[list]
[*] [b] Little-to-no guidance:[/b] After a bare-bones tutorial that only explains the key controls, you are just thrown into the game. Spoiler alert: there is WAY more to the game than just the basic controls. For instance, there are hundreds of different guns you can pick up that each does its own special thing (which is arguably the game's selling point), but the game will not just tell you anything about them beyond its "Ammonomicon" entry, which is more concerned with giving you flavor text than any sort of pertinent information as to how the damn gun works. I shouldn't have to consult the wiki just to know basic mechanics of the game.
[*] [b] Needlessly punishing:[/b] There are so many little traps and mistakes you can run into that will punish you hard for no reason. Like how ammo pickups or items you leave behind in a room will be "stolen", never to be seen or collected again. Or how health pickups when you're at full health show you a "Save For Later" message, implying that if you pick it up you get to bank it on the spot, except what it really does is just destroy it forever. Or how the gun-combiner merchant that takes two guns and gives you a totally new one actually just gives you a completely random gun and not one that is necessarily better than either two you just sacrificed or even one that is [i]good[/i] in an objective sense. Case in point: I once got a Pea Shooter from them once, which is a gun that ends up somehow being weaker than the dinky starting pistols that at least have infinite ammo.
[*] [b] Pathetic characters:[/b] Each of the four starter characters are hella weak and underwhelming. They have low health, their movement speed is slow, and their aim with the guns THEY CHOSE is downright atrocious. The "Marine" has just as much health as everyone else despite literally wearing armor, and is only equipped with a dinky starter pistol. The "Pilot" has a lockpick that has a 50-50 chance of either opening a lock (go figure) or to [b]completely render the lock unopenable forever[/b] (NOT explained in-game) and only starts with a dinky starter pistol. The "Convict" brings a shotgun with so much spread it struggles to consistently kill basic enemies at anything except so-close-you're-eating-their-bullets range. The "Hunter" is the only character I bother choosing on account of her having a hard-hitting crossbow, but the accuracy on it is startlingly shit, often completely missing targets only a third of the screen away (not very far). Maybe there's a way to get permanent upgrades later on, but a feature like that ought to be available from the start.
[*] [b] NPC's hard to get:[/b] The game does something similar to Crypt of the Necrodancer, where the hub world NPC's start out unavailable, and must be unlocked by jumping through hoops to "rescue" them in the game proper. This is all well and good, except in Crypt of the Necrodancer, the NPC's consistently appear in the levels as long as they haven't been saved yet. In Enter the Gungeon, it's a crapshoot whether or not an NPC will even be available to save, and if you fail to save them (either because you die or don't end up finding their key) then there's no telling when your next chance will be. Overall frustrating and, again, needlessly punishing.
[*] [b] Boring soundtrack:[/b] The music is so damn generic and just fades into the background. Positively mediocre and unremarkable.
[*] [b] Game discourages backtracking:[/b] In most rogue-likes that allow backtracking, there's some sort of inherent risk to it, be it an existing time pressure or respawning enemies or some such, with the reward being additional flexibility in approaching your current run, or simply more time to grind currency or items. Enter the Gungeon handles backtracking rather poorly. Your character moves slowly and each of the rooms is rather large (as are the hallways connecting the rooms). To remedy this, the game has it so some rooms have a teleporter pad that you can warp to and from with complete freedom (emphasis on [i]some[/i] rooms...). And yet, as mentioned before, the game has a built-in mechanic that automatically "steals" items you may want to leave for yourself at a later moment, completely defeating the purpose of including this extraordinarily convenient mechanic that otherwise enables you great flexibility with how to approach a run.
[\list]
In all, Enter the Gungeon is a punishing game for all the wrong reasons, sporting lackluster and unremarkable characters, frustrating gameplay, a listless and forgettable soundtrack, and a lack of all the qualities that I've come to love and expect from modern rogue-likes. Maybe someone can add a comment to this review and help me understand what makes this game so fun for the majority of other people, because I can't say I was anything apart from disappointed during my entire experience.

As you know, I love pretentious games such as Nuclear Throne and Galga.
I saw someone on my Steam friend list playing, “Enter The Gungeon”, oh my, what is this? I thought to myself.
I just had to munch on this game, I ran downstairs to find my piggy bank, tucked away in my basement (Binding of Isaac reference, for those who don’t get it) and continued to tackle it.
It had braken, and to my surprise, no money was achieved. I gasped, but remembered that I could steal my neighbor’s credit card, as I was already using their wifi without them knowing.
After I did so, I input the info into Steam and swiftly added the game to my cart. I purchased and installed it. 3 days later it had finished, I achieved the play button.
As I spent 35 minutes changing my settings, I had entered the breach.
I was shocked to see the large cast of playable characters, I decided to play the convict because it reminded me of myself, after I was sentenced to 2 death sentences in Lehigh County Jail in 1985.
I appeared in the game, my first run lasted about 2 and a half minutes, I died of a burning sensation.
Really? I thought to myself. In one fell swoop, I grabbed my keyboard and angrily typed “Enter The Gungeon cheats” into Bing.
I found a little thing called Mod The Gungeon. I installed it instantly and found the debug console made the game quite good. Probably a 6/10.

Overwhelmingly positive? More like overwhelmingly HARD!
And that's a shame, because there is actually a fun game here with lots of unique weapons.

My main complaints are;
1. HP:  Not enough chances to recover health (drop rate is low and shop is expensive)
2. Bosses:  Way too OP
3. Weapon RNG:  Don't find a good weapon on the first floor? Too bad! Forget about winning the boss fight!
4. Room RNG:  Room might be big or small, have few or many enemies. You can be unlucky and enter a small room with lots of powerful enemies and no place to go behind cover. And no, you can't exit the room before you have defeated all the enemies.
5. Weapons:  Of all the weapons I have found, most of them are pretty weak. Maybe good enough for clearing rooms, but useless against the bosses.
6. Levels/Rooms:  Room designs are bland and too repetitive.

This is a very solid roguelike, casual yet difficult. The balance is great and you'll rarely get screwed by RNG, and no matter how good your setup is you need the skill to make it work, so it'll always be a fair challenge. EtG comes pretty damn close to being infinitely replayable, and I've only started to get bored after about the 200 hour mark. You don't need to get invested into the plot or anything like that; the game has a pretty chill tone, and still manages to keep a strong aesthetic and art style. Well worth the purchase if you like roguelikes, top-down shooters, or bullet hell-style games. Just don't get the sequel.

This game comes from a time where roguelikes had a great surge and somewhat a "comeback"... Like many of its friends from that era it is painfully hard and while this is not a huge problem it lacks any kind of meta progression.

And to me that is just the worst thing a roguelike can do. I mean basically you can say after the first run if you are good enough for this game or not. No way of increasing your health or lowering difficulty or something like that. I would not even mind if I can't 100% this game but lacking any meta progression means that your individual runs basically mean nothing. If you find something to unlock permanently it seems to be purely random.

Also most pick ups and guns are somewhat worthless or not really unique. When you find a decent gun it creates basically 90% of your success chances.

Enter The gungeon is one of the greatest Roguelikes out there and a lot of people have a lot of fun with it. Hence why I would recommend it.

It's just not a game for me. The early game is so incredibly boring and tedious I just shut the game down during a boss because I realized I was going to be stuck for the next 10 minutes doing piddly squat damage and dodging everything and then the next few floors were going to be the exact same thing again. I'm probably not going to start it up ever again.

Reasons why it's not for me:
1) The guns are varied and there's some fun ones out there, but it's very stingy with giving you guns... and if your game is based around guns and you get so few, half your selling point's gone.
2) Progression doesn't really matter, you can unlock more guns but you're not likely to see any of them (see point 1 ), There's no character upgrades or ways to speed up the game to make the early game more enjoyable AFAIK, there's no particular reason to try and unlock things and there's nothing to look forward to aside from getting more skilled at the game. Which is fine, but not for me.
3) The Core gameplay loop is not fun for me. This is not a gun-game, this isn't a frantic game, it's only partly about the guns. The core gameplay loop is endurance: How long can you keep dodging bullets? Sometimes you have a very powerful gun and the bosses and rooms take a long time, sometimes you have a bad or no gun and it takes a REALLY long time. The only consistency is that you'll trying to dodge whatever they throw at you. Which frankly isn't for me. 

Again, I still recommend it, a ton of people have had a ton of fun with it, but it's a game that screams tedious to me and I don't feel a particular need to learn to get better at it because of that.
the gun bullet gun

Enter the Shitty Devs is a roguelike that has no multiplayer (a key feature to keep roguelikes from getting stale).
The steam play-together feature is technically enabled, but entirely non-functional in any meaningful capacity.

While it's enjoyable on occasion, it easily takes 10 failed attempts before one even workable turn of RNG comes along and you can survive the first boss.
This can be countered fairly well by cheating for infinite keys and money, but even then it's a overly difficult by the fourth level of the dungeon.

Overall, I Would NOT recommend it unless you're fine with cheating or you're a masochist who wants constant, unplayably bad RNG disadvantages that could only be mitigated with having multiple players in the same session.

You're better off going to play Risk of Rain or Heros of Hammerwatch instead (because those games have decent RNG and devs competent enough to add online multiplayer).

For a game where guns are such a central theme, it's strange to me how poorly they depicted guns in this game. Almost every gun kills super slowly because every enemy has too much health, and boss fights all feel like they take longer than they should. Enemy bullets move extremely slowly, making the entire game, including late and post-game bosses, super easy. Even small things like a lot of weak gun firing sounds make them so unsatisfying to use.

It's not a terrible game by any means but there's much better options for roguelikes or shoot-em-ups. Nuclear Throne, Isaac, Hotline Miami, and Cuphead all offer more satisfying, challenging shmup gameplay than this.

I have nearly 100 hours on EtG in another platform, so I've had more time to experience the content the game has to offer than Steam lets on.

Enter the Gungeon is the very first rogue-like that ever clicked with me. For many of the starting hours, the challenge of making it past 5 floors of the dungeon will feel insurmountable unless you're a gaming god. But you learn, and adapt, and train your muscle memory and eyes to track the myriad bullets and enemies on screen. And with a nice dose of meta progression in the form of guns and items you unlock, the game feeds you more and more arsenal slowly, until the whole thing cracks wide open. And suddenly BOOM, you get your first clear! And then  your second... and they start coming more often, and the rest is history. And don't worry, because once you get regular clears, you will realize there's much more at the endgame than just beating the High Dragun, and that becomes a whole new set of goals.

In conclusion, very few other games have core gameplay this good. The shooting and dodging and gun variety are unbeatable, and I really love many of the bosses.

Enter The Dungeon is brutally difficult but also very detailed and fleshed out. There is no real way to level up your ability, rather the more you play and fail the more you learn about how to beat specific enemies and bosses so whilst it feels like you are making no progress if you keep at it you will succeed. Having said this there is no real reason to sweat it about beating the game as the first level has enough variety and random generation to keep you entertained indefinitely.

Do you like guns? Do you like Pixel games? How 'bout dungeon crawling? What about roguelike? And what about having moments of agony for loosing focus on a good run and failing because of it?
If all your answers were 'yes', then you might like Enter the Gungeon. [b] WELCOME TO BULLET HELL [/b] [i] (kind of) [/i].
Enter The Gungeon is really good for making player to go further and further, and to challenge youself too. In every Chamber there will be new enemies with different weapons/attacks, abilities and different quantities of traps. Game offers you four main characters with their own unique abilities to play as and to complete their side of the story in ETG.
Depending on the run you're having moments of easy can make quite fast 180° turn and get you overwhelmed. Only learning from your mistakes and learning the enemy patterns you'll succeed... or you just have the most dumbest luck and get through the game with easy, that's possible too.
Even when you get passed the "[i] Final Boss [/i]" you still have things to do, for example:
 [list]
[*]Free all the prisoners
[*]Open all the shortcuts
[*][spoiler] Defeat The Past [/spoiler]
[*]Try the mutations to spice the runs
[*]etc etc
[/list]
With all honesty ETG is good [i]pass your time[/i] game even for casual gamers (like myself), it might be hard and challenging at first but more runs you'll have behind you the better you'll perform. From RNG Chambers/floors to alternating bosses and weapons, every run is different and unique.
[spoiler] If you are a streamer, have played ETG through and would like to spice your runs a bit, ask and let your community to decide what to do in your run. [/spoiler]
Game also has local co-op (and maybe online co-op), altho I haven't tried the coop at all so I don't have anything to say about it. 😐 But play it with or without friend(s) I bet you'll be having fun with this game... at least until you don't.

TL;DR ETG is good game, can recommend even for casual gamers and is challenging enough.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Okay so I bought Enter the Gungeon when it was on sale for like 5ish dollars, so keep that in mind.
That being said, this game is very fun! Excellent rogue-like with fun mechanics, interesting items, and super awesome guns. Everything in this game is a gun pun: your health, your bosses, your characters, they're all bullets or guns or shells or whatnot. This game is incredibly silly when it comes to the gun aspect and it goes all out, with interesting concepts and excellent gameplay. I'd say the game is also reasonably hard, but the more you play it the better you get.
HOWEVER, there are some flaws that the game has, such as it being a bit difficult to know how to advance in the game. Be prepared to do a LOT of googling and to download a LOT of mods, especially ones that tell you what the items do and what the rooms are, because without them you'll be lost. I especially recommend health bar add-on mods that show how much health each enemy has, which is something the base game lacks and can make for a really difficult experience, as well as mods that auto-reload and of course the Custom Characters Mod by Kyle (lets you use custom characters in the game). If you don't google every aspect of this game, you'll never know what you need to do in order to get more endings and get further in the game. That being said, including so much information could also interrupt the gameplay flow, so I understand why the game doesn't just tell you what to do and how to do it for the most part.
I love doing Gungeon runs and just throwing myself at it, especially because it's extremely fun to just shoot the guns and dodge around the enemy bullets. The concept is simple and the execution is awesome, I just wish there were more base game bosses and enemies that didn't need mods to be added.
Overall, I highly recommend the game, but I'd wait until it's on sale. Also, Mod the Gungeon is necessary to use mods, so download that first if you do.

A fantastic gameplay experience deeply soured by various miserable design choices.


The fundamental core of this game is quite well designed. The presentation is great, the gameplay is engaging and there is a lot of content to experience. But underneath all that are various features which make the overall experience a miserable chore.

Health upgrades are a massive factor in survival as they significantly extend the player's ability to survive, however finding health upgrades is totally random. It is completely random whether or not a health upgrade shows up during a given playthrough. The only consistent form of health upgrade is acquired by defeating bosses without getting hit a single time. Thus players must hold themselves to the highest standard of never getting hit against the biggest threats in the game just to consistently increase their health to have a far better chance of winning in the end. This consequently makes taking even a single hit significantly more destructive and frustrating because of how much it impacts the run.

The boss difficulty is extremely inconsistent, with some foes being far more dangerous than others. Certain attacks and moments in a given fight are disproportionately more difficult to avoid than others; like when a boss runs right up to the player and shoots at them point blank or random hazards converge in a way that is nearly impossible to avoid. This is a problem in general as even outside of boss fights this kind of thing will happen, but the difference is that if players get hit during the boss fight then they lose their chance at a health upgrade. This makes the standard of never getting hit during a boss fight even more absurd and infuriating because there is so much randomness at play throughout the course of each fight.

Players do have a special mechanic that allows them to escape dangerous situations, but it is a finite resource that doesn't work against certain threats and only works if the player has time to actually react. Thus the mechanic is at best a superficial bandage plastered over a gaping source of frustration and unfairness in this experience.

Most of the overarching unlock mechanics in the game are tedious and run contradictory to enjoying a run. Having to get lucky with hoarding and then burning a bunch of resources to unlock various things at various moments, having entire swathes of content or resources locked behind the player discovering obscure secrets, carrying an item all the way to the final area which drops out of the player's inventory every time they dodge and it disappears if they forget to pick it up again all just to unlock a thing, having to purposely do a certain unintuitive thing during a totally random moment multiple times to unlock something else, having to jump through obscure hoops and sacrifice resources to acquire certain items then successfully bring them all the way down to the final area to unlock an extremely important thing.

The game also offers special challenge modes, which require the player to grind resources just to even attempt them. The actual challenge modes merely afflict the player with random effects that randomly make things more or less difficult, thus making the challenge modes a gauntlet of luck.



The base gameplay of this experience is amazing; a varied, potently atmospheric and compelling rogue-lite. But most of its deeper mechanics are just totally miserable chores, which contort this otherwise amazing experience into a miserable chore. Ransoming almost any amount of meaningful progress behind obnoxious tasks largely driven by repetition, luck and self-sabotage.

This is my comfort game. I mean it when I say this, Enter The Gungeon is one of the BEST rogue-likes ever made! The mechanics are so simple to pick up on that I'd recommend it for casual players. The gameplay is so fun and addicting in a way that you'll want to continuously play indefinitely. Every boss in the game is unique in how they attack, and the enemy variety is numerous. In a game with gun in the name, there is a HUGE selection of firearms for you to use, from classics like the .44 magnum and the mare's leg, to sci-fi blasters, there is so much to play with. Not only is there a lot of guns, but there are numerous secondary items for you to utilize while you delve deeper into the Gungeon. The artstyle is GORGEOUS, hats off to developers and designers. Its definitely my favorite rogue-like and I have feeling it will be yours too.

I wouldn't call it a bad game, but it is definitely not 100% for me.

The game is good, has characters to unlock but every run feels the same, I would compare this to the Binding of Isaac, a game in which every run is completely different but in here... it's not the case.

Every run is the same and very rarely do you get a synergy, the floors feel repetitive since... there's little randomization and it gets to be a little bit boring after a while.

It's still good to play once in a while though, so I would give it a 7/10 personally.

[h1] A Truly Masterpiece [/h1]

[b] GamePlay [/b]

Once again, I happened to be more engaged by the indie games rather than AAA stuff. Enter The Gungeon present [i] solid mechanics [/i]. The conjunction of them all are clearly thought to walk along with Dynamics, even though actions like rolling or table flipping are common enough to be boring, the design of the enemy bullets, and levels make them pretty fun, as you feel inmersed on a gunfight. Unfortunately after some hours (I have some hundreds on ps4) flipping tables are not as usefull as in the begging of the experience. 

[i] Comedy [/i] in this game is very important. Is not an deadass boring comedy like several movies, the game has a tone of sarcastic comedy that feels great but not overwhelming, just a right amount of it, and it's the heart of the game. Something I really like is having stories told by the description of items and weapons, they produce in you a touch of nostalgia and mystery  because of the abandoned dungeon context; they are *incomplete*, letting you imagine the rest of it. several items and weapons have a touch of comedy that it just makes me laugh, and others got me thinking about how that story could continue, something little games make me do willfully. Actually, this is one of a million games that encourages me to read as much as I can about the internal lore, it's just great. 

[b] Enjoyment [/b]

The lack of [i] Fun [/i] as a topic in movies and game reviews makes me think of incomplete analysis. Good games are design to be an experience more than just a game and even though a game's mechanics are common and etc... if you had fun playing it, something went well in the design. It could be the aesthetics, player's curiosity, the tone, blablabla. But Enter The Gungeon makes you wanna play the game, because it is just FUN. The overall possible combinations, the npcs, lore, guns itself gives you an amazing amount of fun to interact with. Discovering a gun that throws guns that shoots bullets is just amazing. 

I know the review is incomplete and i'm rambling to much in my topics, but I wanted to exposed those not so common great points about the game, and I am to lazy to continue rn and to summarize.

By far, my favorite rougelike, plenty of fun references and plenty of fun ways to play the game, no real need to mod things in my opinion, as the base game has plenty of different ways to make your runs fun. The gameplay loop leaves you wanting more every single time.

I been looking everywhere for roguelike games and I came across this one I actually played a roguelike or rogue lite that game was neon abyss I played that one and it got boring but it was pretty fun but then I heard of Enter the Gungeon I actually played this one on the ps4 one time but I don’t know how I felt about the game back then but I did actually like the art style the pixel art style graphics are really cool I find them really unique so when I first saw this game on steam I bought it immediately and started to jump in and play the game felt a bit clanky at first with KB and Mouse but when I saw that game had controller support I tried it with a controller it still felt a little bit clanky but when I played the game more and more I got used to it so the clanky feeling went away that was my only issue with the game everything was smooth sailing and still was.
The game was a bit difficult at first but after watching some guides on YouTube I finally learned how to play and succeed only issue I have with the game is that some runs can get boring after a while that’s because those runs were unlucky run, and I had a bad luck so I received really bad things like guns and items, but it doesn’t happen that often anymore it only happens rarely.
The characters are cool like the marine with a shield I used to do my runs with him, but people say that the hunter is also good for beginners cause the dog can find you items like hearts, ammo and other stuff (and the fact that you can pet the dog is neat). and you also have second weapon the bow, the bow is awesome the enemies got no chance against you when you use the bow.
The music in this game is good the intro music sounds good as well and when you beat a boss that awesome soundtrack plays.

I recommend this game to anyone that like roguelikes 10/10

[h1]Stairway to (Bullet) Heaven[/h1]

Everyone has regrets: something you wish you did, something you wish you didn’t do, something you just want to forget. So how far would you go to kill the past? Would you stare down hordes of enemies, explore an ever changing labyrinth, only to die and start again from the beginning? Would you… Enter the Gungeon?

In Enter the Gungeon, you play as one of the Gungeoneers: people with deep regrets who explore the mostly randomized Gungeon to find its great treasure, a gun that can kill the past. Each of them start with different weapons and items. For example, my favorite, the Hunter, starts with a rusty pistol, a crossbow, and a dog. The pistol has unlimited ammo, but is weaker than other character’s starting weapons. The crossbow is powerful, but has a long reload time. And you can pet the dog when it occasionally digs up extra items for you. All of the Gungeoneers have their pros and cons, but all of them feel viable and can use any of the Gungeon’s countless weapons. You can use the weapons you discover in chests throughout the Gungeon in satisfying and fun ways; from the baseball bat to hit back bullets to a gun riding a skateboard, every weapon is unique, incredibly creative, and have well written descriptions in the game’s Ammonomicon. You can play as a bullet, using a bullet that shoots shotguns which shoot bullets. What more could you want?

Everyone has regrets: something you wish you did, something you wish you didn’t do, something you just want to forget. So how far would you go to kill the past? Would you stare down hordes of enemies, explore an ever changing labyrinth, only to die and start again from the beginning? Would you… Enter the Gungeon?

In Enter the Gungeon, you play as one of the Gungeoneers: people with deep regrets who explore the mostly randomized Gungeon to find its great treasure, a gun that can kill the past. Each of them start with different weapons and items. For example, my favorite, the Hunter, starts with a rusty pistol, a crossbow, and a dog. The pistol has unlimited ammo, but is weaker than other character’s starting weapons. The crossbow is powerful, but has a long reload time. And you can pet the dog when it occasionally digs up extra items for you. All of the Gungeoneers have their pros and cons, but all of them feel viable and can use any of the Gungeon’s countless weapons. You can use the weapons you discover in chests throughout the Gungeon in satisfying and fun ways; from the baseball bat to hit back bullets to a gun riding a skateboard, every weapon is unique, incredibly creative, and have well written descriptions in the game’s Ammonomicon. You can play as a bullet, using a bullet that shoots shotguns which shoot bullets. What more could you want?

You probably want to explore the Gungeon. Each time you enter, the layout of each floor is randomized. Instead of complete randomization, every room is purposefully designed, and the game draws upon a large pool of them to create the level. This stops the game from generating cheap death traps, and instead you get… fair death traps. You can also find various secrets on each floor, from hidden rooms to entrances to secret floors. Each floor offers an abundance of choices to make each foray interesting and, more importantly, fun. Do you visit the shop to buy a new weapon or replenish your health, or do you head straight for the boss? Do you use one of your precious keys to open a chest, or do you save them to fix the elevator to start your next run on a lower floor?

The Gungeon itself is also gorgeous. All the enemies, characters, and weapons you encounter are colorful and intricately animated. Every single one is memorable, which makes it very easy to remember their attacks or how they can help you. The bosses especially are a visual treat. They all have an intro screen with some very detailed pixel art, and it’s easy to tell how each will attack you just from looking at their design, even if you’ve never encountered them before. After defeating a boss, you get some currency that stays with you after you die. You spend this in the game’s hub on weapons and items to add to the pool of treasures you can find in the Gungeon. It helps to add a sense of progression without making it feel like you couldn’t reach the end of any run. One of my favorite parts of discovering new items is to read about them in the Ammonomicon. Their descriptions can range from funny absurdity to interesting lore. I would open the menu every time I got something new, or sometimes just to watch the animation for opening the book.

Speaking of menus, which are all intricately detailed, Enter the Gungeon has some of the best options menus in any console game. You can adjust practically everything about the game, including button mapping and graphics settings. You can also set some options to change when you’re playing co-op with a friend. More games could really use an options menu like Gungeon’s: Why isn’t button mapping standard in every game?

While Enter the Gungeon is partially a bullet hell, you have plenty of time and options to avoid every single shot that comes your way. Every enemy and boss has a distinct shooting pattern, which incentivised me to deal with the ones I felt less confident in dodging first. If you can’t dodge by moving or rolling, you can hide behind walls or flipped up tables, and if all else fails, you can use a blank to erase all bullets from the screen. And thanks to the generous amount of aim assist, which you can also adjust or turn off, you never have to stop shooting. This along with all the different weapon types and items makes every single encounter feel strategic and different. It can feel exhilarating clearing a floor without taking a single hit, or just scraping by with a sliver of health left.

Enter the Gungeon is a game for everyone. I play co-op often with my little brother who mostly enjoys sports games and shooters. It has enough random chance that less skilled players can get lucky, and experienced players don’t have to rely on lady luck. It’s funny, frightening, cute, fun, and fair.

Points about the game so far:

+ 4 starting characters, +1 co-op, +4 unlockable (Gungeoneers) with different starting weapons and abilities (active/inactive items).

+ Huge variety of weapons and items of which many provide buffs when used in tandem.

+ Challenging and interesting bosses.

+ Ability to roll: dodge bullets and become invincible to them for a short period and get over gaps.

+ Blanks: Remove all incoming projectiles and push enemies away.

+ Beautiful pixel art and cool level design.

+ Armour and hearts or health bullets.

+ I really like the portals; you can quickly travel around in the current chamber (floor).

+ Shops with random assortment of weapons and items you can purchase with the bullet currency. Sometimes there are health dispensers and NPC's.

+  Chest rooms (requires a key to unlock). Sometimes non-locked chests spawn after clearing a room of enemies.

+ Hidden rooms with rewards

+ Target rooms with increasing rarity of loot rewarded the more targets you hit.

+ Unlock rooms and save prisoners with golden keys (princess peach).

+ Thrones and gifts from goddess.


The RNG (randomness) aspect can make some runs very unfair and some lucky.

Its generally a challenging game which requires practice, dedication, 
smart plays (which enemy/ies to prioritize, positioning, taking cover, when to play aggressive or passive, timing of rolling and using blanks) and 
planning (what to purchase, sell, trade in etc..) if you want to progress far. 

You should also experiment with all the gungeoneers and see who you like, fits your playstyle or which playstyle each one is ideal for.

An addicting "Bullet Hell" game with a high skill ceiling, taking around 30 hours to properly beat. Everything in this game is a pun, usually on guns, and you can never get enough of it. All guns and items are, although sometimes overpowered, fun, unique, and engaging, elevating the game to its best. Finding out powerful combinations and creative ways to use guns and items makes for some incredible fun. Bosses are mostly well-designed around dodge rolls and blanks and are always charming and difficult. The plentiful secrets compose some of my favorite parts of the game, but they are sometimes so ludicrous to find that you should consult a guide. Finally, the music is fitting and great for background, and the credits music makes you feel incredibly accomplished. Overall, this is a great game that anyone can enjoy. Definitively worth its price in a steam sale.

Imo, even within the vast genre of the "rogue" genre, there are only a few roguelikes that are better than enter the gungeon. This game is very unique and is so unbelievably complex and vast that's under a cover of what seems like a simple bullet hell type game. The amount of secrets that exist in this game is honestly insane, and between the vast amount of items and guns that exist in this game to the different challenges and game modes that it brings, it truly embodies what a good roguelike game should be. I will say though, this game gets so tilting sometimes, which I don't really mind, as it's really a part of any roguelike game.

This is one of the (if not the best) Bullet Hell games I have EVER had the pleasure to come across. I was a bored, misguided, lost, and broken child with 15 dollars to my name.. I needed to give it to something, but alas, nothing piqued my interest... Until I saw it... On the Nintendo Shop, a beautiful gem, a diamond in the rough if you will. Except this diamond was polished, clean, and dazzling. I saw the cover art, a simple yet enticing Bullet Kin running.. "From what?" I wondered. My heart pounded as I had to find the answers. I looked into it, "Enter the Gungeon? That's a stupid name.." is what I thought, little did I know I had found The Garden of Eden of games.. But instead of angels protecting it, a paywall... A 15 dollar paywall... I was skeptical, so I searched up a video. A video that made me question all I knew about my life, and more. Was I destined to find this gem? Is this God saying I am his child, this is what I was meant to have? The video was not only engaging but informative.. I decided to download the game, and that was the best decision of my life... I opened that game and I saw him.. The Pilot, Dash as "Dodge Roll" appeared, trying to crush him. I always thought myself a straight man, but when I saw that sexy rapscallion dash through, I didn't know what to think. I loaded in and was met with pure bliss. Four starter characters who all called out to me... I knew I had to play them all! I got onto my character, The Huntress and walked down into the Gungeon.. The orgasmic feeling of shooting a Bullet Kin, the satisfying tingle of killing a Gunnut.. They never faded, it was mesmerizing. Whether it was a Bullet King, Bullet Twins, and a damn Bird, I COULDN'T CARE LESS! THEY ALL BENT TO ME, THE ONE WITH THE CHAMBER, THE ONE WITH THE POWER AND THE BLANKS! Have you ever had an orgasm before? Of course not. You know why? You have never had the Cactus, Fat Bullets, and Blank Bullets whilst being the Gunslinger. The average male produces 1.5 - 5.0 millilitres of semen every time they finish. I produced 5 times that, and then some. Do you know what that does to someone? It makes them addicted, it made ME addicted. I played for hours, days, weeks, months on end on my tiny Nintendo Switch Lite. I had everything.. Everyone.. I was completely done... But I felt empty.. My heart yearned for more.. So I got onto my PS4 and downloaded the game there too. A fresh start, a new life. I enjoyed the game with friends. And I got to enjoy it all again.. And so I did, until I beat it on there too? No.. No.. That can't right.. It's only been three weeks this time.. I HAVE TO DO IT AGAIN, I NEED TO SHOOT ANOTHER BULLET KIN DOWN WITH JUST A STARTER FIREARM! So I got it on my pc.. It was only better then.. Better and better, this game only gets better! Until two weeks in, I did it: I got 100% on the game on pc. My room now coated in white, I finished... I leaned back as I saw that final achievement. I did not want to reproduce, I had never even considered it, until this game. I want to bare children so I can make them shoot the Shotgun Kin as they smoke the Defect with a Molotov as I hear them say "Dad.. I know my purpose in life now." Thank you, Dodge Roll.. Thank you for this tingly experience I have been able to enjoy for years and more to come. I do not just "recommend" this game, I implore you to get it. If you are unsure, don't be, Kaliber and her children are waiting. And I suggest bringing some tissues, because you will finish before the game does..

Simple, yet very fun.

Pros: Good core mechanics, pixel art, colors, references, music
Solid Difficulty Curve - you typically aren't asked to do something you can't do or haven't been trained for
Each character's past is fun to play through
Solid jokes/humor throughout

Cons: 
The Wiki is a MUST
This game does not respect your time - Frifle's Challenges will wall you out if you want 100%
No matter how good you are, the game manufactures its own longevity for the sake of lengthening playtime
Challenge Mode (Daisuke) is ATROCIOUS - having beaten it, I can guarantee its not worth doing. You have to study every effect and READ every effect on every room, effectively slowing down the flow of the game.
Rat fight 3rd phase: extremely weird choice to unceremoniously slap another game's mechanics over here with no practice mode whatsoever

Conclusion: Good, solid game you can sink your teeth into. Lots to love and enjoy, despite flaws

I've played a few indie roguelites in my time. Some like Hades or Inscryption are shining examples of what the subgenre is capable of, others like dead cells have great gameplay but are so completely insulting that they retroactively make the rest of the game bad (un-subtly asking for money after a single completed run to add new areas to the game is seriously bad form), and some like enter the gungeon are just a resounding apathetic "meh".

The game works. The game is functional and I have not encountered a single bug or glitch in my 16 hours of gameplay. You shoot your gun, you dodge roll and you open doors; every single aspect of it works.
However that's really all there is to it, and the gameplay is just 'fine' and nothing else. Nothing about this game is bad, while at the same time nothing is truly rewarding or satisfying or makes you feel like you're really making progress. And while I haven't finished it, I'm about ready to throw in the towel.

A vast majority of the guns I've found are either dumb gimmicks or just don't do any damage, and as such, it's the only roguelite I've played that feels almost entirely reliant on luck. Other games of the genre do rely heavily on luck as well in order to put together a decent build on every run, but you can still manage to squeak by if you perform well enough. In ETG though, every single battle has so much crap flying everywhere in tight, confined spaces that just about every combat encounter becomes less a test of skill and more a battle of attrition. If you get to a boss and you haven't found a decent weapon, it's faster to just restart the run, because most weapons are so comically weak that you will be fighting long enough to make costly mistakes regardless of your skill level.

The only actual progress you make in the game is adding new weapons to the loot pool, new npcs in the gungeon itself that show up very rarely,  and opening shortcuts to later floors. But it doesn't really add much to the overall gameplay like upgrades in other games do, and so it feels like you're constantly spinning your wheels without going anywhere and I just can't muster up the desire to keep going.

As a final aside: this game is so kwerky that it's physically painful. Not once did I laugh at the game's lame attempts at humor [spoiler] "See it's funny because normally guns shoot bullets and not the other way around." [/spoiler], the enemy designs make my eyes roll into my skull, and while some references to other media are a nice touch like [spoiler] Barrett's arm cannon from FF7 [/spoiler] it only sparked my neurons because it's referencing something I love, and not because the game made something cool or funny itself.

All in all, while ETG isn't a bad game per se, it's not nearly gripping enough to entice me over the finish line. Gameplay is all it has, and the gameplay is just ok and nothing more.
