Gungeon is an action-packed roguelike with great weapon variety and a fun set of levels to play through. What gungeon lacks in the "build crafting" aspect compared to games like The Binding of Isaac, it makes up for in charm and style.

Ok so where to start? I guess first I gotta say, this is one hell of an amazing game, one of my all time favourties.
It's fast paced (it is bullet hell xD), like many other rouglikes you can just play one run from time to time and still have plenty of fun, it has relatively easy to learn mechanics that are not so easy to master and the 2D art is just so lovely, not to mention that soundtrack is also amazing, especially the menu track. And the world! Everything is a gun! It is both insanely creative and so funny. If you want both fun and challenge then you found a right game. 

Here underneath I have a bigger description for those who like to read xD:

=== Bullet Hell ===
Ok so you know how I mentioned bullet hell mechanics? Well there are A LOT of bullets on the screen, especially when dealing with bosses. This game is gonna test your ability to dodge just in time, to erase bullets with scarce "blanks" you will gather through the run and to manouvre around the room to not get yourslef cornered. You will die, but from each death you will come back wiser and after a while you will learn very well how to counter various enemies Gungeon will throw at you. 
=== Rouge-like ===
I am a big fan of rouglikes, even though not every one of them hit that sweet spot. This one deffinetly did though. Combination of bullet hell and rouge-like makes for fun and challenging gameplay. The vaast amount of both active and passive items makes for a very fun gameplay where sometimes you gonna get run-winning item on first floor and sometimes you will struggle with mediocre items and then it will all be down to your skill xD
Each playable character will require you to adjust your playthrough a bit (or more then just a bit) and the enemies will test you even after you get pretty good (you will also get frustrated with some, I sure did).
=== Lore ===
Throughout your runs you will gather pieces of stories for each playbable character, some of the NPCs and also wider story of The Gungeon, the magical gun-themed dungeon with an ultimate prize - a gun able to change your past, to kill time itself. I don't want to spoil too much with this section, but let me just say that the lore is fun, some characters have pretty nice if simple stories and progressing in game will reward you with some new fun characters (with rather unique traits) and variety of new items, so dig deep and get ready for a fight! 
=== Enemies ===
Both mechanics and designs for those are just so fun. They start off as pretty easy and simple, slowly becoming tougher and FASTER then anything that game throws at you at the start. Example? Bullet-kin, the most basic enemy, will have quite a few different varinats, some pretty tough for basic enemy of each floor. Don't wanna spoil too much here either so let me just say that you better watch out once you reach the final stage, The Forge. Enemies are overall very fun design wise too, most themed around guns and other weapons and explosives, I think from various rouge-likes I played this game might have my personally favourtie design choice for the enemies.
=== Bosses ===
This game has some very fun bosses providing a decent challenge. There are 3 possible bosses for each of the first 4 floors (you can get one of them at the end of each floor), with the main boss of the game waiting for you at the end of the 5th floor. Each one has its own unique way of fighting you so you will need to devise a strategy for each, some will keep you constantly moving with their quick attacks, some will make you carefully move throughout the stage with their wide spread attacks, one way or another, you will need to learn how to dodge xD.
There is a bunch of extra bosses too, some will spawn randomly throughout your runs, one will rpelace a random basic boss and some will await you on end of each secret floor. 
And last but not least there are bosses of each character's past. No spoilers here, but they are all fun fights and very fitting for each character's past. But be warned, messing with time will also get the attention of Dungeon's Master, so stay alert.
Oh and fu#k Ammuconda, you will learn why. 
=== Wrap-up ===
I could keep going about this game for a while, talking about all the fun deisgn choices for items, about how fun some NPCs are or how much of a bop main menu theme is. But I think best way to enjoy this game is on your own, I hope you dear reader will find this review helpful or at least entertaining enough to play the game, enjoy.

This game is very good, however, it tries very hard to be more difficult and less fun than it is, especially with the random elements.
While the enemy patterns and boss fights are pretty much skill based, your experience each run varies WIDELY based on the items you get. Some items are great, some are just fine and the vast majority are borderline useless and unfun. I cannot express enough how much more fun rainbow runs are, because you can get some cool weapons and items and just experience more of what the game has to offer you. A lot of the time in regular runs I realized I just wasn't having fun because I'd take a lot more time to clear floors and bosses because I had to use the default weapon, or some terrible item and gun and run out of ammo for it. The ammount of times I'd restart a run on floor one/two because I got 3 D-C quality weapons in a row is more than I can remember.
This is not to mention a bunch of hidden mechanics and item descriptions and synergies left intentionally vague that will just result in you opening a wiki to see what it does. We are not on the SNES days anymore where these things would have to be figured out through repeated playthroughs and discussions with other players, there is not much reason to not have these things explained in game on a menu.
I kinda wanted to give a lower score, but since I've played so much there is definitely something engaging and fun to this game. It just tries really hard to not let you experience it.

The Gungeon is both Hell and Heaven.

Amazing game.  
Pros:
- combat is difficult but fair
- well balanced RNG - you can win with most loadouts (in contrast to games like Binding of Isaac where balance is quite poor)
- fun synergies to look for during runs
- most additional game modes are fun
- extremely replayable
Cons: 
- trap rooms - rooms with horrible puzzles, in some of these rooms damage is very difficult to avoid - ideally there needs to be a practice mode where the player gets the chance to learn how these work because it took dozens or more attempts before I grasp how some of these rooms even work let alone complete them without getting hit
- rat punchout - similar to trap rooms this needs a practice mode to learn how to play this very niche part of the game
- there is no audio cue when you get hit and a very faint visual cue -- so sometimes you don't even know you've been hit
- challenge mode - it's awful - really sucks the joy out of the game; you need to memorise many different room modifiers and react to them as they pop up together in random variations; some of these variations aren't well thought out and can lead unfair rooms

I like the aesthetic, the sound design, and the bones of the game, but there's too many frustrating elements to the game for me to enjoy it.  Too much of it is just feels tedious instead of challenging.

It's not the Roguelike or Bullet Hell elements that are putting me off the most, it's the fact I never feel like I'm making any sort of headway.

Other games in the Roguelike genre always make the player feel like they're getting somewhere, even if a run doesn't pan out.  Dead Cells always feels like I'm making progress, even in failure.  Same with Rogue Legacy, Hollow Knight, even Binding of Isaac.  But EtG is all stick and no carrot.  Why am I going to try to grind runs when every run feels the same as every other run, other than the minuscule chance that I'll find one of the guns I unlocked (that turns out to be even weaker than my starting gear)?

Health bonuses shouldn't be gated behind not needing them.  You shouldn't have to mag dump all but the most basic enemies to kill them.  Item unlocks shouldn't feel pointless, but they do.  Most guns are about as weak as your starting gun, and that's only IF you get a useful one from a chest.  And "better" guns and items are all but guaranteed to only drop on later levels, the same levels that most players will need the good items to even get to.

It's just an exercise in tedium.  Maybe I'm not "gud" enough.  Maybe I'll never "git gud" enough.  But in order to "git gud," there must be something worth "gitting gud" for.  And in EtG, there's a big fat nothing.

Want to know how to bake a cake of any kind? Whether you're making a simple pound cake garnished with fresh fruit or spending days on an elaborate multilayered cake with multiple fillings and frostings, there are a few key tips that apply to all cakes. Cake baking is not necessarily difficult, but it does require a little organization and forethought—and these cake-baking tips will help you get your homemade cake right every single time.

1. Read through the recipe

This sounds obvious, but cakes in particular have certain requirements—such as the oven temperature, baking time, and ingredients—that cannot be altered. You don't want to realize too late that the butter you just mixed with sugar was supposed to be softened.

2. Assemble ingredients and ensure their correct temperatures

Get all of your wet and dry ingredients and equipment out on the counter before you begin and make sure that everything is at the proper temperature. This is especially important for butter and eggs: Soft butter makes for a smooth batter and a lofty cake, and room-temperature eggs keep the batter's temperature consistent.

To soften butter, leave it out for several hours; it should offer no resistance when you press on it. Or you can hurry the process using a microwave: Cut the butter into 1/2-inch cubes, arrange them in a single layer on a microwave-safe plate, then microwave on high for 3 seconds at a time, testing in between, until the butter is softened but not melted. Melted butter won’t hold the air you need for fluffy cakes, so keep an eye on it!

3. Preheat the oven before you make the cake batter

Before you begin, position the racks correctly: To avoid burning your cake, set a wire rack in the middle of the oven for cake layers or in the lower third for a tube cake, so that the top of the pan is not too close to the top of the oven.

Before preparing the cake batter, preheat your oven to the correct temperature. This might take awhile, and it’s best to use an oven thermometer to confirm; many ovens won’t report their temp accurately. You want to wait on mixing the batter because it will not react properly to heat if it sits at room temperature for 10 minutes waiting for the oven to get hot. Nor will your cake rise properly if the oven continues to warm up after the pan has been placed in it.

4. Prepare the pan

To ensure that your finished cake has the right shape, it's important to make sure that it will come out of the pan in one piece. The most common way to do this is to coat the pan with butter, but the specifics may vary depending on the type of cake.

For cake layers in general, you coat the inside of the pan with very soft but not melted butter using a brush. Follow that with a disk of parchment paper cut to the size of the inside of the pan. (Precut parchment paper sheets are a luxury we love to have on hand—get some to match the size of your cake pans.)

For a butter cake baked in a Bundt pan, coat with soft butter, and then coat the buttered surface with fine, dry bread crumbs (or finely ground nut flour), tapping the inverted pan to dislodge any excess. Follow with a quick coat of vegetable cooking spray for a guarantee that the cake won't stick.

Line a rectangular or square pan with foil by molding the foil first on the back of the pan, then pressing it into the pan. Butter the foil. This makes it easy to lift a cake that you don't want to invert, such as a crumb cake, right out of the prepared pan.

5. Prepare the batter

Instructions will vary depending on the type of cake: For butter cakes, ingredients will typically be combined using the creaming method; for sponge cakes the eggs will generally be beaten, then folded in. For the proper texture, be sure to follow the instructions closely, and then pour the batter into the pan or pans and bake.

6. Avoid undermixing or overmixing

It's easy to get carried away when mixing, but remember, the goal is to simply combine the ingredients. Overmixing will deflate necessary air from the batter and leave you with cakes that have a tough texture. On the flip side, of course, don't undermix. All the ingredients need to be fully incorporated.

7. Don't open the oven door

As tempting as it might be to crack open the oven door to sneak a peek at a cake in progress, resist the urge. Opening the oven door lets in cool air and significantly changes the temperature inside. That change in temperature can wreak havoc on your cake.

8. Test for doneness

To test a cake, plunge a thin knife, cake tester, or toothpick into the center (or halfway between the side and the tube if using a tube pan). When a cake is finished, you will find a few crumbs sticking to the knife or toothpick when you withdraw it. If the cake is not ready yet, wet batter will still cling to it.

9. Cool the cake

Most cakes are cooled on a metal rack for even air circulation. A recipe will indicate whether the cake should be cooled in the pan or unmolded immediately. Follow instructions carefully—leaving certain types of cakes in the pan for too long may cause them to stick. Angel food cakes and chiffon cakes need to cool suspended upside down in their tube pans or they will deflate and look squashed and unappealing when you cut them. Invert the pan over several inverted ramekins so that the edges of the pan are supported by them. It is best to figure out the system for doing this before you begin baking the cake by testing the empty pan over the ramekins to make sure your system will be stable.

10. Unmold the cake gently

When you are ready, gently run a sharp, thin knife between the edge of the pan and the cake. Then invert a rack or platter (as indicated in the recipe) over the top of the pan. Turn the pan over and lift it off the cake. You may be asked to finish cooling the cake upside down or instructed to turn it right side up again. Be sure to follow instructions, as each type of cake cools best in a different way.

11. Finish the cake

The options for finishing a cake are numerous. Some varieties, such as pound cakes and crumb cakes, are finished already when they come out of the oven and don't need any embellishment at all. For others, a simple dusting of powdered sugar or quick brush with a glaze may be all that's required. And some cakes, such as European-style layer cakes, can be filled with multiple fillings, frosted with a different frosting or glaze, and then adorned with elaborate decorations, such as piped buttercream or marzipan crafted into roses and leaves.

This is a fantastic game, with amazing gameplay mechanics. Every run is unique or different. Hundreds of cool items & guns, that make up cool synergies and combos. So much cool stuff to do! The NPC's are fun and unique. Lots of puns and humor. Writing's good as well.

The game definitely has a deep learning curve. There is a lot of learning by the hard way, kinda like Dark Souls. Thats what this game is, 2D gun Dark Souls.

After many hours of playing, learning and knowing the Gungeon, it only gets better. Your character doesn't get better - you do. In the end, you can complete the Gungeon with every run - no matter your weapons or items. 

You will start to understand the levels, the rooms and enemies. You'll know when to dodge roll, and when not. You know how to handle your economy; your keys, bullet casings and items. 

And when the Gungeon feels too easy.... Try out the different challenges. You can always make things harder...

I came into this with 600 hours on The Binding of Isaac thinking I was hot stuff before this game pulled out all my bones and put them in backwards.
This game was an absolute joy to play for a really long time and I love it to bits. There's a bunch of different game modes to play, some tough characters, some crazy over powered character, lots of unlockables, ever going quests, that sort of stuff. I personally haven't been super interested in continuing with the game after unlocking everything but I know tons of people absolutely would keep playing for a few hundred more hours.
Also as someone who's only ever used keyboard for every game I play, this is the only game I *actually* recommend controller for. Having an 8 directional roll compared to a 360 degree roll really sucks, though aiming could be harder on controller so pick your poison.

Maybe I'm just a sucker for rogue likes and twin stick shooters...but honestly, this is one of the best games I've ever played.

Absolutely addicting and perfectly polished gameplay. The envrionments and characters are fun and it doesn't take itself too seriously. After all, its a game about bullets shootings guns that shoot guns that shoot bullets. The humor is not laugh in your face funny, but enough to keep the game entertaining and charming. There are many nods to other indie games you will notice.

The weapon types are extremly varied. I would go so far as to say more varied than just about any other game I've played. Make no mistake, this game is brutally difficult, and after almost 300 hours I still haven't fully completed it. 

If you're up for a grind and okay with permadeath and rogue like gameplay, this game is a must buy if it looks fun to you. Seriously one of the best pick up and play twin stick rogue likes I've ever played. 

Won't be stopping until I 100% this one.

Edit: It took me over 400 hours of playtime, but I finally 100% completed this game. Loved every minute. Cannot reccomend enough. There is enough challenge and variety here to keep you going for hundreds of hours.

Will go down as one of my all time favorites.

No matter the price tag, there will always be a better option for a roguelike than this game. If it's your first roguelike, sure. But under any other circumstance, just play Dead Cells, Tiny Rogue, Have a Nice Death, Hades, Noita, Darkest Dungeon, hell, even Gunfire Reborn which I personally heavily dislike. Even after its final update, the game feels heavily unpolished and major challenges built into the game lack any creativity, like a specific hidden character requiring you to lap the game twice and defeat a "Glitched" version of the final boss that's literally just the same guy twice, but one's jammed! Additionally, I've never had to pull up a wiki as much as I have for this game, as gun descriptions and ammonomicon entries are only minimally helpful if at all. This game sacrifices context and articulating information on guns and items for the sake of trying to be funny.

All I can really say is that the soundtrack is good and the pixel art is pretty okay. Fun when you're a middle schooler, downright painful when you've played the genre enough to realize, even after 40 hours of revisiting to 100% the game, that anything could be better than this.

Enter the Gungeon is a fast-paced, bullet-hell shooter developed by Dodge Roll. The game was released in 2016 and has since become a cult classic among fans of the genre.

The game's premise revolves around a group of characters who have entered a mysterious dungeon in search of a powerful weapon known as the Gun That Can Kill The Past. The dungeon is filled with traps, puzzles, and waves of enemies that the player must navigate and defeat in order to progress through the levels.

One of the key features of Enter the Gungeon is its vast array of weapons and items. There are over 200 unique weapons in the game, ranging from standard guns to bizarre and fantastical weapons like a shotgun that shoots fish or a gun that shoots bees. The items in the game can also drastically change the way the player approaches combat, offering everything from temporary invincibility to the ability to slow down time.

The game's graphics and sound design are also top-notch. The pixel art style is charming and the enemy designs are creative and memorable. The soundtrack is upbeat and energetic, perfectly complementing the game's frantic action.

One potential downside to Enter the Gungeon is its difficulty level. The game can be punishingly difficult at times, which may turn off more casual players. However, the game's procedurally generated levels mean that each playthrough is unique, which can help to keep the game feeling fresh and engaging even after multiple attempts.

Overall, Enter the Gungeon is a must-play for fans of the bullet-hell shooter genre. Its unique weapons, items, and enemies, combined with its top-notch graphics and sound design, make it a standout title that is sure to provide hours of entertainment for anyone willing to brave its challenging dungeons.

This is the best co-op game me and my wife have ever played. We played this game all the way from we first met till our marriage, which was...about a year. We really wanted to keep playing this game but there was nothing else for us to do except killing the rat. That fighting game part was too difficult for us with too few chances to practice, so we thought it was time to move on. 

Afterwards, we hadn't found a game as good as Enter the Gungeon except perhaps Overcooked. The time me and my wife playing this game together was the best time we had ever had. Although we have moved on to play many other coop games, we have yet to come across a game that can replicate the experience we had had in Enter the Gungeon.

The Variety of guns, items and unlockables is outstanding and the synergies are a fantastic way to make lower tier items and weapons viable and fun and adds a ton of variety and they can even completely change the weapon. For example: lower case r can go from B U L L E T, to uppercase r which goes R O C K E T and shoots explosives. The combat is fast paced and room variety is pretty great. Characters are all unique and fun to play, i like the bullet which requires skill as if you get a single half a heart lost, your OP damage sword turns to a very bad damage dealer. My god the amount of little details and references this game has is mind blowing and don't even get me started on all the secrets and easter eggs where even after playing for hundreds of hours, you will not have seen it all! The music is insanely good and makes me turn up the volume on bossfights so Doseone did a fantastic job. The roguelite elements are well balanced so that every time you die its(mostly) always your fault for dying and not the RNG, and yes... this game requires immense skill to master, but the feeling of satisfaction when you beat a boss for the first time is great and very rewarding to always unlock new things. I would give 10/10 but if you dont enjoy roguelikes or roguelites, this might not be for you as when you die, you guessed it... back to the start. Only bad thing I can say DAMN YOU JK-47.

Utterly addicting gameplay, phenomenal soundtrack, and a fun feel to the game! Lots of love CLEARLY went into this.  Extra points for all the references and homages they were able to organically build into this gem.

I am a 51 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2016 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 30 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he friended and invited me to join him. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.
Easy top 10 games I've ever played, to the point I bought the game on steam to play it again.

I do believe this game is an "acquired taste."

Despite this being a roguelike, runs are EXTREMELY repetitive to the point(for me at least) where I only find fun when I get as far as I can. This game has lots of charm and lots of care put into it, but the repeating cycle of drop in, get items, and die makes it easy to get exhausted of restarting runs over again. I have to sit down and take a break from it before I want to play again, it's not like other roguelikes I've played where each run is different from the last, progression in this game is molasses slow.

I really would love to see what this game has to offer in terms of guns, but every run just feels like it has little to offer, and that might be because of the brutal RNG(Which of course has been a little more gracious thanks to the new update). Due to the low amount of items that you can get(I only ever get like 2-3 chests on floor 1) I feel like chests can make or break your run as well as items.

Sure, there are good and bad items in every roguelike, but in games like the Binding of Isaac, even if I do get bad items I still manage to find some fun in it. Repeated attempts don't burn me out in other games as much as Gungeon does.

I will say the new Advanced Gungeons and Draguns update did make the RNG a little more merciful and added some neat quality of life changes though, maybe I just haven't played it enough.

You will die in this game A LOT. I die in this game A LOT. Practice makes perfect.
Though I do wish there was an area where you could practice fighting against bosses in the hub, that would be nice.
Or make an arena where you can add enemies and equip weapons and items, similar to what Crypt of the NecroDancer has in its lobby.

I have a massive love-hate relationship with this game, sometimes more hate, sometimes more love. The number of reasons why for both are pretty neck and neck, and I can't deny this game's vision. Though the game burns me out quickly and shuts me off from ever seeing more content that I probably won't see until my umpteenth run, the items and guns and all this game has to offer are truly unique. The artstyle is great, the quirkiness is great, its sense of humor is wonderful(I still can't get over how the main enemies are bullets firing guns, it always amuses me!), and the difficulty is equivalent to listening to Nickelback, which is already hard enough as it is.

But hey, that's just my opinion on this game. It has a lot of flaws, but it has a lot of things it does right.
Now if you'll excuse me, I'm gonna brb and turn these 40 hours of gameplay into 400 hours of gameplay, ta ta for now!

When revisiting this game I was expecting to still hold my original feelings towards it, which was that I would not recommend this game because I feel like other roguelites from supersede it, I thought it to still be a solid game on its own standing. But after playing it for a bit I was shocked by how dull I found the experience. I feel like I was basically handed a victory with the ridiculous amount of powerful weapons, ammo refills, and health/keys I was given. I stumbled across a few 'synergies' which weren't bad but felt totally arbitrary and not intuitive, rather like a random upgrade I stumbled upon. I went to the bonus challenge final world and the main thought on my mind was how dull it felt. I didn't even feel the need to use any blanks, which are the game's limited use panic button.

The final nail in the coffin was when I went to play another run on the game's "fast mode," only to find out I was already playing on it. If I was this bored already, I cannot imagine playing the same game but slower. [b]Just play Nuclear Throne or The Binding of Isaac or Hades instead.[/b] If you've already played those and are looking for something else, keep looking. Those games have a much more compelling gameplay loop and a lot more run customization than Gungeon does. I respect these developers for putting out several FREE content updates and this game has a sick art style and themes but I just cannot recommend it. I'm shocked I even played it for so long when I was younger, the gameplay loop is just so so mediocre...

Found this game very underwhelming. A huge selling point is the sheer amount of guns in this game. Almost all of them do the exact same thing with very little to change how they work. It's just boring. All the interesting guns are rare and it doesn't feel rewarding to just reroll for them - so enjoy your gun that has the same stats as the starter pistol except it pierces 1 enemy.

Also, the bosses are all a damage sponge. It feels like a war of attrition rather than an actual test of skill. If you have bad DPS (which you always will because the guns in this game suck) you will probably spend a few minutes just sitting there doing the exact same thing. More waiting.

With over 60,000 reviews and a rating of "Overwhelmingly Positive", odds are you will neither find this review, nor will you pay it much attention. However, as I am here, and Steam requests that I offer up my opinion, I'll explain my experience with the game nonetheless. 

For the tl;dr, 
while the game has several things going for it, and even I could give some positive words, I'm afraid my experience with it as a whole was nothing more than a solid "meh". A strong "meh", to be sure, but a still a "meh". 

And if you would like a little more detail, then read on. 

The music is decent, the art style is fun and very much enjoyable, and even the controls are tight and feel good. Marry all of that to "mostly alright" level design, amusing attack patterns from enemies, and hilarious weapons, you'd think you'd have the recipe for success. Or at least awfully close.

I played the game both in its original state when it was much, much harder, as well as after a big update that loosened up the difficulty a fair bit. As I played, I found myself starting out having a good time, but the farther along I got, the more I disliked the game. 

I'm no stranger to dying and losing in video games. As someone who has played games since the original NES days, I'm a strong believer that seeing the game over screen is very much part of the process. Sometimes you win, sometimes you don't. 

So why, then, was Enter the Gungeon such an unfulfilling experience when it came to the increasing difficulty the farther I went? 

I decided to be a dirty little cheater one day and gave myself infinite ammo. Whatever new gun I picked up I could use as freely as I wanted. As I ran through the levels spraying an assortment of lasers, bullets, ducks, hammers, eggs, and maybe even the occasional rainbow, I realized something. 

A large portion of the weapons in this game, while amusing, aren't very good at performing their primary function, which is to kill the enemy. Instead, it would seem they focus more on bringing humor to the situation while simultaneously poking your nostalgia bone. Several guns are spoofs from other games or movies, or even treats from the real world itself such as the NES Light Gun.

The more I played this way, the more I realized the problem. The balance. It's off. 

And while balance is a very subjective thing, another issue I find with the game is a bit more concrete. 

It offers little to nothing more than what many other games on the market already offer. It has some traditional rogue-lite issues, such as explaining very little, expecting you to run through the same thing over and over to progress something an inch at a time, and of course, some RNG dependency. 

The market might have been a bit lighter in this genre back in 2016 (though doubtful), but Lord knows it's beyond overly flooded at this point. 

After completing the 5th floor, I was basically informed that there was more to do in the game, which I will assume means finding more random NPCs along the way to progress something that hopes to be at least a shred of story and perhaps more levels, all RNG dependent. 

I don't know if this is actually the case or not, as I have zero desire to play through again. 

CLOSING THOUGHTS: 
While Enter the Gungeon's initial impression is something unique and potentially great, it ends up wearing out its welcome relatively quickly, and brings very little to the table that can't be found elsewhere. If you find this game on sale for a few dollars, then I'd say it'd be worth the time and money. Anything more than that though, I can't say I recommend.

[h1]Bomblastic's 1000+ hour, totally unbiased Enter the Gungeon Review[/h1]

[hr][/hr]

Let me just start this review by saying I have NO IDEA why it took me 1070 in-game hours and literally unlocking every item and achievement in the game to finally write a review on this absolute masterpiece, but whatever, better late than never, right?

[hr][/hr]

[b]PROS:[/b]

-Tight controls that are easy to pick up but hard to master. 
-Fantastic, addictive rogue-lite elements. 
-Engaging, memorable characters and storyline. 
-Tons of references from everyone's childhood (I can guarantee you'll find at least one familiar, beloved weapon from one of your favorite childhood shooters.) 
-Nearly endless replayability with thousands of unlockable items, synergies, secrets on top of secrets on top of secrets, unlockable characters, differing game modes, and much, much more. 
-Goofy, endlessly charming art style that flawlessly combines grittiness and cartooniness. 
-One of the hardest, most rewarding slogs you'll ever face in your life. 
-[b]GUNS. LOTS OF GUNS.[/b]


[hr][/hr]

[b]CONS:[/b]

-Steep learning curve, which can honestly be considered a bad or a good thing based on your perspective. 
-There is a [i]small[/i] amount of jankiness, and not the good kind (I can't tell you how many times I've tried to dodge roll over a bullet only to dodge into a table and take the hit while sliding over it.)
-May cause rage-induced controller destruction. 

[hr][/hr]

[b]Summary:[/b]

Enter the Gungeon, for me, was one of those fresh new ideas that just seemed too good to pass up when it was first released. If only I'd known how deep down this particular rabbit hole I would end up diving...
Enter the Gungeon will chew you up and spit you out if you aren't used to games in this genre, at least at first. But personally speaking, the feeling I got when I realized I was good enough that I could reliably clear the game every attempt was one of the greatest, most rewarding feelings I've ever had. 
This game reminded me how much fun it is to completely absorb yourself into a seemingly (at the time) impossible game until you finally see yourself overcoming those odds that seemed so unreachable, all that time ago. 

[hr][/hr]

TL;DR:

[h1]10/10, ABSOLUTE GEM OF A GAME, WOULD RECOMMEND TO ANYONE WHO LIKES A CHALLENGING, NOSTALGIC, EXPANSIVE ROGUE-LITE.[/h1]

I think this game has amazing passion behind it and the developers are clearly really passionate about what they do.
However, I really struggle to recommend this game. 
I have about 50 hours in this game over the course of a few years, and I really really tried to get into it. I even got all the pieces for the bullet and got to multiple characters pasts (I didn't beat any but honestly at that point I was so frustrated that I didn't care) 
This game is so close to being fun, but in reality I think the RNG mechanic of this rouge like is dragging it down. 
I feel like the game is far too dependent on getting a good gun in the first 2-3 stages of the game or else you're fucked. I feel either like I'm a total god walking among mortals, or a nobody that dies instantly. it doesn't feel fun to flit in between these two modes. The game play loop is simple enough, but without the right guns it doesn't feel very rewarding to be plinking away at enemies with your starting gun, or the Winchester or whatever you happen to get out of the 3000th blue chest this run. That's the other issue with the RNG, the amount of blue chests I have seen that have given loot that is not even remotely exciting is an issue. So many of the cool rare items completely change the way you play the game in unique and interesting ways (Ala the bloody scarf or the super hot watch), and you just don't see enough of those in your run. 
I can see why so many people like this game, but I simply can't put any more time into it when more fun rouge likes exist like risk of rain 2 and hades.

Something about this game feels horrible. Like, I actually hate this game even though it is fun and I appreciate it for what it is, and the overall art. I enjoy the challenge of getting a good run and I'm still busy grinding out all the secret bonuses.
Pros: Most creative game ever made, best character and enemy design, ridiculous replay value compared to other games in the genre, fun weapons, gun reference, compelling NPC quests and objectives, entertaining dialogue, fantastic art, lots of endings, story line?
Cons: 
Game play: I feel there are a lot of elements that are disrespectful to the player in many ways. Two examples are: some guns shoot faster if you click your mouse faster. I call this out for disrespecting equipment because it is shortening the life span of my mouse severly. Another example is disrespecting gamer's time and effort, there is an enemy that is hiding in a wall and it gives you an item so if you want to get more good items you have to walk along every wall and most of the time you'll never find it. There are some technical problems too. This game makes my computer fans sound like I'm playing ELDEN RING, it's like its mining bitcoin or something which makes no sense to me based on how simple of a game it should be to run. Before I moved it to my SSD from HDD every time I killed an enemy there was a frame loss during its death animation and there is still frame loss if you dodge very close to a bullet. Clicking the teleport pads on the map and selecting items in my inventory to see their desctiption is not synced to where my mouse actually is so I have to spam click around until it registers the mouse over or drag the part of the map I want to teleport closer to the center. There's even an item in the game that literally gives you infinite ammo and lets you shoot as many bullets as you want in like 1 second of game time and its not like I had to get this item several times to find this bug (I think its helix bullets in combination with the stopwatch), found it within a minute of having the item the first time. The game designers decided to add no player sounds to the game so when you are accumulating poison, on fire or being cursed there is just a small indicator above your head that fills up in about a second then hits you out of nowhere. Although I put the variety of items as a pro leading to replay value its also a huge problem; some runs you will get 13 mediocre guns and 1 or 2 passives (this happens to me frequently!) other runs you will only find one weapon in a level other runs you will get 3 god guns and 5 defensive items making it not even a challenge to win. A lot of the activatable items are trash while only a few are sought. Another super annoying problem is actually the enemy models and hit boxes, sometimes bullets can fly through your head (because of the fake 3D aspect) and other times they graze a semi pixel of your toe and hit you. I get hit mid dodge roll frequently.  Just because dark souls does it doesn't make it a good mechanic. The movement speed is so high on keyboard that often you can go to dodge a bullet and walk so far that you hit the next bullet. Games are supposed to be fun to play and reward skill, not inconsistent and unreasonably punishing, the hit-box should be more generous and then you can make the game more thrilling by adding more bullets. Also there's a mechanic where you can roll into enemies to hurt them but this just puts you right at their feet and then they almost always walk into you causing damage, I'm not a fan of damage on non-attack contact, this is a gun game not a platformer, on that note I hate when enemies spawn right under you if you aren't looking around rapidly all the time you get hit by a fading in enemy. The way enemies hold their weapon can vary but sometimes its 100-150 pixels away from the enemies body and the bullets just appear instantly moving from the edge of their weapon so you have to stay WAY farther away than you would intuitively, and the screen is so small that this makes fighting certain enemies a horrible game play experience, also their bullets will often go around corners and hit you behind walls even though it looks like you are on a very safe angle, like its way more than you'd think if you just read that sentence and hadn't played it yourself. There are all these curses and shrines and I have no idea what half of them do because I haven't looked up a wiki yet and I don't think players of ANY game should EVER have to look up a wiki, even after getting the buff several times and still not knowing what it does, unless you want extremely technical details or player guides. There is a mode that changes your guns randomly and they were too lazy to program channel weapons like lasers differently than charge up shot weapons, so you get 0.2 seconds of laser fire and then your weapon switches.  Its SO stupid.
Control/Movement: I play on mouse and keyboard so my movement and dodge rolls are limited to 8 directions which can easily be mistimed to cause wrong direction and although it seems like they put a tiny bit of effort to account for this I'm sure its a massive handicap and barrier to enjoyment. What makes it even worse is that so many enemy attacks space the bullets apart perfectly so if you dodge one bullet you land on the next bullet making dodging a 50/50 death wish. There is an option to move faster out of combat (who wouldn't turn this on?) and the problem with it is that it activates the second you kill the last enemy, the jolting shift in movement speed can easily make you run into traps or bullets that are still flying around the map. WHY NOT ACTIVATE IT WHEN THE BULLETS ARE ALL GONE? THAT IS CALLED BEING IN COMBAT!!! This also causes issues when you walk into a room because the room is black and lights up but its very easy to walk so far in that you walk into an enemy or trap or a hole before the room has lit up because of the crazy fast movement speed. Something about the controls bothers me too. I don't usually struggle to press the right buttons in games but due to the nature of this game you want to NOT use blanks and activatable items as much as possible, meaning it takes dozens of hours of play to develop the neurological training to press the correct buttons without thinking or wasting your blanks or actives. I'm good at it now but it took a while and I still forget to use actives sometimes. Often I use my blank and the bullet still hits me. I changed all the controls to space-dodge, alt-use, middlemouse-active, mb4-blank, mb2-reload.
Screen layout/Graphic: The screen shape and enemy models are designed in a way that makes fighting horizontally optimal, but using W-S halves your dodge reaction time compared to using A-D since its only your middle finger pressing WSWS vs pointer/index's ADAD so that sucks a lot. On top of that jerky mouse movements can cause the screen to shuffle around rapidly making it very difficult to track the actual direction bullets are travelling.I really do hate how limiting the screen vision is, most boss fights you don't even see the boss half the time. But I appreciate the concept that if you are looking far to one side of the screen you cant see whats behind you. Its jarring that there are bosses where the screen zooms out and becomes stationary, actually I just wish the whole game was like that like other bullet hell games. Another jarring thing is the vorpal gun. It fires a random bullet that is so powerful it pauses the game randomly and its awful.A lot of these complaints are combinations of control/screen/game play issues but I think this sums up everything I don't like about it.  In closing, the achievement rates of this game are abysmal. Seems like not many people have the patience to endure all the downsides.

Enter the Gungeon is the greatest homage to videogames ever made. This is the Platonic Ideal of every shooter imagined by kids who were intelligent enough to ask "what if there was a game that had every gun?" It is the litmus test for videogame weaponry; if there's any semblance of notoriety to a weapon of mass destruction, it's in here. 

Gungeon has great visuals, a well-paced difficulty curve, catchy tunes and more Easter Eggs than you can count, but you're not here for that, you're here for the guns.

I truly loved this game! It's fast paced bullet hell madness is the perfect blend of challenging and fun. This has got to be my favorite indie/rogue of all time. The game is beautiful and the homage to sci fi movies and video games is amazing and hilarious. You'll get your butt kicked but it won't matter......get back in there and go flex on that dragun! THE FORCE IS STRONG IN THIS ONE!

Tragedy. Absolute tragedy. I will do my best to describe the flaws of the game, but if you're wondering to buy it, you're gonna play it for 5 hours max due to it's lack of balance.
To start with, probably the worst flaw of this game is scalability. After completing 2-3 floors you gonna end up in one of two scenarios: 1) You are gonna run out of bullets for all of your weapons or 2) You start to feel like doing damage is not enough. This is because there is a lack of scalability - enemies are getting stronger and you are only getting guns with limited ammo and primary. This could be fixed by adding selective upgrade for primary weapon at the end of the boss level so you could use your resources accordingly.
Secondly, the coin system is off, usually you'll end up having enough money to buy yourself one heart or one key, which is nothing considering one floor requirement.
Third and the last point, movement prediction. This game aims for realistic player predicament meanwhile ruining the game experience. You usually end up wondering why bullets are flying in all directions instead of firing towards your initial spot.
Of course I wanna mention missing features for auto-reload and no practical use for game's interior (interactables). I do appreciate the work put into this game's development and the vision that was put for realistic western shooting game, but it just does not cut it.
Overall, if you find yourself enjoying the game as a whole, but struggling with game flow, I suggest installing mods, which help out balance most features of the game. I found myself helpful auto-reload, item description and enemy health scalability reduction.

Enter the Gungeon is a game that really stands out in the crowded field of rogue-likes. It offers challenging gameplay that requires skill and strategy, but it's also very rewarding when you make progress. The variety of weapons and items available is impressive, and it ensures that each run feels unique. The pixelated graphics are charming and the soundtrack is great, creating an enjoyable atmosphere. The quirky characters and witty dialogue add personality to the game. As a gamer who's played many similar titles, I can confidently say that Enter the Gungeon is one of the best in its genre. If you enjoy games like Binding of Isaac or Dead Cells, you'll definitely appreciate what Enter the Gungeon has to offer.

If you like bullet hell shooters and rogue lites which are brutally difficult then you know what you're getting into and are probably already familiar with Enter the Gungeon. For those not in the loop, this is a game where you repeatedly have your heart broken and compulsively hit replay just to have yet another 50 minute run ending in nothing but despair and no measurable progress toward the goals you're currently pursuing. Like an emotionally abusive partner Gungeon is crazy, charming, addictive, and draining all at once. The colors are vivid, the soundtrack is banging, and the builds synergize in all sorts of fun ways. Sure, there were many times I hit Alt-F4 just to boot the game back up a minute later, and if that sounds exhausting to you, it's because it is. But to my fellow masochists, Gungeon is definitely an exhilerating rush which you should check out if it has somehow eluded you all these years.

I like funny guns, which this game has a lot of. Hard to play multiplayer, don't play with controller, really difficult if you relax even just a bit. Incredibly fun, I revisit it every month or two for a few hours, and have definitely gotten my money's worth.

Very glad I decided to revisit this game! I love how charming and charismatic the whole aesthetic of Gungeon is, from the character's expressions and animations, to the text descriptions and even the sound design! The gameplay loop is also pretty fun, especially when you get the hang of the first few floors and bosses and start discovering new things with each run. If you enjoy top-down shooty roguelites, this is probably worth your time.

It's worth pointing out that there is a lot of content and unlockable things that you have to figure out completely on your own, so it can sometimes feel a bit discouraging. But, if you're a hardcore completionist, it'll probably give you a lot of quality entertainment.

In all honesty, this is one of the most enjoyable games I have ever played. You could probably call it art.

The graphics, the MDA, enemy creativity, and the dad jokes are outstanding. It's a great game to try out even if you're not typically into extreme roguelites. This game practically introduced me to roguelites and it was truly love at first sight. I couldn't rest until I had discovered everything: guns, items, more guns, enemies and bosses, guns, unlockables such as guns, and uncovering every secret (including guns).
In short summary, I HIGHLY recommend this game.

If you're the type who'll get frustrated easily and expect to beat games with little effort, I recommend you stay way, but if you're looking for a challenge like the old days of gaming I say this is a must buy!

Enter the Gungeon seems at first an impossible, rage-inducing and hopeless challenge, but at some point in your suffering, you'll start developing not only a keen understanding of the game's mechanics, but an instinct shared by all accomplished gungeoneers. You'll start weaving through bullets like nothing, and your clutch rolls will come to you quicker than you can think to make them. Discovering this ability within yourself is a magical feeling, and once you have it, you become addicted to that flow state it induces.

Enter the Gungeon is a challenging but fun experience. It took me a while to beat the game but the journey was fun!

If you're set on beating the game, then I can definitely recommend playing it once (or more) every day. It will help you to learn enemies' attacks, movement patterns and when to roll or dodge by moving around.

I played the game sporadically here and there and could barely get past the second / third levels. With consistent practice however, I managed to beat the game in about 2 weeks (by playing a few days during the day).

It's tough and sometimes you're at the mercy of the guns and power-ups you get. I do recommend unlocking as many items / guns you can to succeed on your runs. And definitely, try to beat the first few bosses without taking a hit to get better rewards and more health! At first, I thought that it would be insane but after a bit of practice, I managed to beat quite a few bosses without taking any damage. The only solution here is "get good".

Dodge and roll to avoid bullets, take covers whenever you can and do not rush your runs. Practise a bit every day and you'll have a lot of fun.

I've had a great experience and can definitely recommend Enter the Gungeon to those who love a good challenge.

And by the way, the soundtrack is awesome!

As a fan of action-packed rogue-like games, I can say without hesitation that Enter the Gungeon is an absolute must-play. The game's vast arsenal of weapons, challenging bosses, and procedurally generated levels kept me engaged for hours on end. I particularly enjoyed the game's humor and nods to gaming culture, which added to the overall experience.

The game's tight controls and distinctive art style are also worth mentioning, and the addition of a co-op mode made for even more fun with friends. I appreciated the variety of weapons available, from traditional firearms to more imaginative ones like a shotgun that fires bees.

Overall, Enter the Gungeon is a standout game in the genre that offers an addictive and rewarding experience. If you're a fan of challenging action games, I highly recommend giving Enter the Gungeon a try.

Enter the Gungeon is a game that I love and hate. Sometimes I’ll have a blast and other times I’ll direct a number of mean spirited comments at the developers. The level of challenge is complete bullshit and can lead to the game feeling both punitive and incredibly tedious at times, but for the majority of my playtime I’ve really enjoyed Gungeon. The level of variety, the feel of the game, the tangible sense of improvement, and all the little references makes for an experience that begs to be played again, and again, and again. I’m glad I gave Gungeon a shot because it is one of the most fun games I’ve played all year.

Full review here: https://frostilyte.ca/2021/07/27/that-one-about-enter-the-gungeon/
Lots of fun, its hard but fair. Plus its extra fun with local co-op.

Enter The Gungeon is such a great game. It's a challenging game that when you eventually master it, it feels satisfying. Deaths don't feel unforgiving, when you die it actually feels like its your fault for having the biggest skill issue known to mankind instead of the game being like "L + Ratio" (Unless its challenge mode which the game likes to throw plenty of "L + Ratio" deaths at you because challenge mode is genuinely really stupid if you get the unfair modifiers that make you have to play extra cautious). So many wacky guns and items to collect, so many synergies to discover, so much enemy variety, plenty of challenging bosses to fight, tons of secrets to discover, and overall a lot of content to play. I highly recommend ETG because what other games have a bullet that shoots guns, allows you to kill a living explosive using explosives,  a gun that shoots cheese, a shotgun shell that shoots shotguns, a gun that is a literal key, a balloon gun that shoots tornado's and gives you flight, a gun riding a skateboard, and so many references to various different games and movies. If you like bullet hells and rougelike/rougelites, this game is a must have.

Enter the Gungeon is a fantastic roguelike twin-stick shooter that I never regret purchasing or spending time on, nor would I hesitate recommending it. There are games that are so good that they become the benchmark by which you compare all other games in the same genre: Enter the Gungeon is one such game.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

[h2]The Guns[/h2]
Half of the game involves pointing your gun in the direction of the enemy and firing, and the star of the show (as should be expected) are the wide variety of guns available to use; each of which feels fresh and unique, which is quite an achievement for the game. The functional differences of each gun, along with the ammunition system are good ways to force the player to use a variety of guns within a run - some guns are powerful but have low ammunition and are best reserved for bosses; some guns are good in clearing rooms; and some of the rarer ones are so powerful that they trivialize the game. While some guns are better than others, it’s fun either way; getting a good gun feels like winning the lottery in a run, whilst getting a bad gun feels like a challenge to overcome. 

[h2]The Enemies[/h2]
The other half of the game involves dodging the bullet hell coming your way, and if any aspect of the game could outshine the guns, it’s the wide variety of enemies, each with a distinctive attack pattern to dodge against. While a single non-boss enemy is usually not threatening, it becomes more fun and frenetic when several are shooting at you at a time, keeping you on your toes and constantly strategizing on which target to prioritize. 

The bosses are also well designed and a good challenge, each with their own gimmick and multiple attack patterns to look out for. From floors 1 to 4, the bosses are randomized from a pool of 3 to keep things fresh. Each playable characters also have a unique true-ending boss, and along with sub-bosses and secret level bosses, the dungeon feels fresh and varied upon revisiting.

[h2]The World[/h2]
The game is light on story, which is fine since it’s not a story-driven game. You play as one of several characters who have regrets and are searching for a gun that can kill the past within the gungeon. Enter the Gungeon has a lighthearted atmosphere infused with pop-culture references, where everything in the dungeon is gun-themed. Through repeated runs, you progressively unlock more guns, items, NPCs, and playable characters, which mostly mean you get more toys the more you play (and there are a lot of them).

There are a multitude synergies obtained through having a certain combination of items and/or guns in the inventory, most of which are pop-culture themed. The non-gun items are also interesting, though like guns, some are more useful than others. 

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
This is one of those games you need to keep the wiki open, as the in-game codex isn’t as informative, or as navigable as pressing ctrl+f on gun/item wiki pages; which you may need to understand synergies, or to see what guns/items in shops do.

The punch-out fight with the rat is another reason you need to keep a web-page open; it’s very memory-based and you may rarely even get to it. Frankly it’s not fun to stop the core gameplay, rewatch a youtube video on how the punch-out fight works, before resuming the boss fight.

Enter the Gungeon is normally in the top charts for being one of the best roguelikes to buy on steam at the moment. That is a very tall order considering there are many, many great roguelikes that exist and vary in depth and quality. However, I do not think this is one of them. I don't even think it should be considered a "great" game either, I would dare say it is a pretty average to mediocre roguelike, allow me to elaborate on why.

To start off with, we can begin with what I believe is good about the game, the pixel art. It's very high quality and very detailed at times and I have lots of respect to the animators and artist who worked on this, as I do with anything art related. My real issues lies within the mechanics of the game, and how it all blends together.

Firstly, the Co-op is laughably bad in this game. That is not to say that other roguelikes had not struggled with this before, but for whatever reason in this game your ally is forced to play as a random character that has NO personality, or relevance to the gungeon. It feels as if this character was slapped into the game to serve no other purpose other than to be "Player 2" which is the worst offense than not having a co-op mode at all. Personally, if there was no co-op to begin with I would have been more appreciative of that instead of what we had gotten. Was it too difficult for the developers to make it so the 2nd player can play one of the other characters that the 1st player can? It really does not make any sense as to why this is. 

Next, the concept. This game was heavily inspired by "The Binding of Isaac" and how chaotic that game can get with your luck with items, and the developers went on record to say that wanted to emulate that. From last I had played, there is so little item synergies it makes you question where a majority of them went, if at all. There are some items, but it feels they are so few and far between that honestly I can't what they were going with the idea if they weren't gonna go all out with it. They went half way which again, I feel is much worse than if they stuck to it, or didn't do it at all.

 The Binding of Isaac is what I like to call a methotical roguelike, in which you play the cards you are dealt. You have to play it slow, and consider all of your options. With this approach you'll be able to win every single run and even turn a bad run into a good one. However, in this game it is all luck to the cards with no wiggle room for change. Am I saying there is no skill involved in this roguelike? Absolutely not, at its most fundamental level the idea is not to get hit, and if you can manage to do that you are rewarded with a max Hp upgrade, which is all nice and dandy, but that's not what im referring to. Im referring to is item drops. Your guns have ammo and need to be replenished frequently, and ammo is NOT a common thing at all. A point can be made with Isaac as well, since bombs and keys are also luck. The difference between that and this game is that bomb and keys are optional, and you can win a run with minimal key/bomb luck, but in this game if you have no ammo, you pretty much have no weapon besides the dingy starter weapon. Which again, you can argue that you can win with only the starter weapon, but the game revolves around the wacky guns you find, and if you cannot even use those a majority of the time since you have to refill 15+ weapons, it is a poor idea in concept.

The next thing I'd like to comment on is the actual combat of this game. Well, it doesn't feel terrible (in some places) but it is pitifully slow, and its clear that this game not trying to be. Isaac runs can be long, upwards of an hour, but like I had mentioned, its a methotical roguelike which makes sense. Nuclear Throne (a game this was also inspired by and much better) is fast paced action and has the same general concepts and fits the mold of what it wants to be much better. This game feels like everything, your bullets, your enemies bullets, your CHARACTER moves like its stuck in tar. It is so sluggish that an enemy could shoot a bullet at me, and I could get up, get a cup of water, run a 10-mile jog from my home and back, return back home, and the bullet would still be flying at me at "mach speed." Why is the game so slow? I will  never truly understand, and because of this a run could take upwards of an hour to complete. 

Rolling in this game also feels like complete shit, and this is a core mechanic of this game. It feels very mechanical, and the reason why this is, is because you're locked into one direction upon starting your roll. This is very similar to Dark Souls 1's roll which is nearly identical to it even down the the invicibility frames. The issue with taking inspiration from Dark Souls 1's roll is that, that iteration of the roll was not perfected and was the first of its kind, and for whatever reason, the developers of this game used that roll as the "basis" for their game. If they wished for the roll to be invincible throughout they could have easily used a different iteration of the roll, like Dark Souls 3 and kept the I-frames, but chose not to for whatever reason. Because of this mechanical feeling roll, platforming feels awful in this game, and I loathe when I have to get to a room where I must dodge bullets instead of fighting enemies. Which this leads into my next point funnily enough.

Platformer rooms, where you must dodge bullets in order to progress. Normally, these can be fun in other games, Isaac has several puzzle like rooms, and dodging rooms and for the first time they can be a challenge. However, in this game, what they consider a challenge is bullet spam. There are several rooms in the game where there are quite literally just walls full of bullets spewing them out constantly, and you must be hampered down by a small platform moving really slowly and you're expected to dodge them all as you move along. Its generally not fun, and is challenging just for the sake of being challenging, which is always not fun.

So far, we've established that this game has poor multiplayer function, general lack of understanding of the type of roguelike it wishes to be, sluggish combat, and unintuitive rolling, among other nitpicks. If none of these things bother you, then go ahead and get this game. However, if you wish to play much better roguelikes with better understanding of the genre, play Nuclear Throne, or The Binding of Isaac. I would like to reiterate im not some hater of the game or anything, I just wish the game had done better in these departments that I had mentioned. I have spent well over 100+ hours on the game and unlocked everything in the base game, so I have a good amount of knowledge of the game and its mechanics. This game is not the worst thing on steam or anything, but this certainly is one of the most disappointing games Devolver had released. It had a lot of potential and the bag was fumbled royally.

Just a truly fantastic game all around, it's all there for a Rougelike. Solid gameplay, distinct artistic style, addicting RNG, clear progression, and a challenge. The game has a high but tangible skill cap, I knew when I was getting better at the game when I could make it to the Dragun every run regardless of my build, or when I could get Master Rounds from the first three floors consistently. By the end of my tenure with the game, I could see the fruits of my labor just from playing the game regularly. I took a break in the middle somewhere, but even when I returned I was locked back in. 

I was also impressed by the fact that my last play-through of the game to unlock my last achievement coincided with my final attempt to unlock the Gunslinger Gungeoneer. Even got the Makeshift Cannon on that run, it was truly epic and eventual; it felt like a sign of great progression design. And, well, it happened like 5 mins ago so I'm still excited about it. Not much else to discuss that you wouldn't find out for yourself by playing!

Enter the Gungeon (ETG) is a charming, bullet hell, roguelike, and content-filled game. It is quite possible for a player to clock well over 100 hours into this game and barely see all it has to offer. It’s “one of those games” in which it would be largely beneficial to the player to have the wiki open at all times, and as such, offers amazing replayability. 

I had always known about ETG and had known it as “that game where everything is related to guns and it’s really hard,” which would end up being pretty accurate in the end. But it wasn’t until it became free for a limited time on the Epic games store that I actually first downloaded the game and played it for the first time. I logged about 10 to 15 hours on Epic, in which at first, I found the game to be really frustrating. It became clear very quickly that there was a very large skill ceiling that had to be reached in order for a player to make progress. The only time where I would make it past the fourth, maybe even third floor consistently would be if I had powerful weapons and/or synergies. Yet, I enjoyed the challenge, and continued playing, finding my enjoyment and striving to improve only to continue to grow as I continued playing. I had one run in which I made it all the way to the high dragun, the farthest I had ever gone in a run, but died during the fight. That was the point when I decided to move over to steam. Somehow, my progress carried over from my Epic games save to my Steam save, and I began my process of trying to beat ETG. 

As of writing this review, I’ve clocked in around 235 hours, the most time I’ve ever spent playing a steam game; the addiction I developed to this game was something I only ever experienced when I was younger, a time when I had all day to sit around and play video games. I’ve 100%’ed the game, and have unlocked the finished gun, but alas, I have not fully completed the ammonomicon, something that will probably elude me for the foreseeable future. I actually completed all the achievements at around 200-ish hours, but ended up spending an extra thirty to unlock the finished gun. Through my time playing this game, I’ve seen basically all it has to offer, secret bosses, rare drops and rooms, and some crazy events that percentagely should not be possible; I fully acknowledge that I’ve had a LOT of luck with some of the drops I’ve gotten (5 glitched chests…). 

Firstly, I want to talk about how the game manages difficulty and how it relates to the player’s progression in skill. As I mentioned, it becomes very clear early on that there is a very large skill ceiling that a player can reach, but as the player gets more hours under their belt and begins to better understand the ins and outs of how a run plays out, that skill ceiling can become reachable, which is what I think caused me to clock so many hours.  I think ETG has done an amazing job at scaling the difficulty of the floors and bosses. Each floor is a step up in difficulty, enough to thoroughly challenge the player in multiple areas, whether it is their dodging, bullet accuracy, or resource management, each floor is a new challenge the player must tackle. The bosses fights are difficult and rewarding; beating the high dragun for the first time is an awesome feeling, and the glitched lych is a worthy “final boss.”

In regards to it’s “genres,” it’s pulls each one of them off masterfully. The most important part of the game is dodging, and some very clever, creative, and most importantly difficult bullet patterns are thrown at the player. Enemies are great, I really enjoyed the challenge that some enemies presented. Along with room layouts, as I started noticing and remembering the placements of enemies, it was clear that a lot of thought went into enemies placement in each respective room layout. The devs really handled this game with care, and the room layouts and enemies are designed wonderfully. 

Of course, I have to write about the guns. One of the best parts of playing throuhg this game is discovering the crazy ass guns that you can use, and on top of that, discovering the even wilder synergies. All of this makes the game so replayable, there’s so many different gun combos, synergy or not, that you can play around with. There are also a TON of reference to any and all sorts of media, it was really fun to see. 

The art design and pixel graphics are really well done, some areas and enemies are designed and colored beautifully. In particular, the high dragun never ceases to amaze me in how well it’s designed and “drawn.” 

I really enjoyed playing ETG, and I highly recommend it for any fans of the bullet hell and rougelike genre.

I love completing hard games. I beat cuphead without much trouble, dark souls, etc. I've played this game a fair bit, but am no where close to beating it; this is because you have to beat the whole game on a single life. So, this game calls for a level of mastery that you might see from DOOM ultra-nightmare speedrunners. I'm ok with this, because procedural generation keeps things (somewhat) fresh, but it does get old running through the first few levels just to get back to the point where you're pushing your progression.

This game is definitely worth your time and your money. But mileage may vary. I could see certain people disliking this format.

A great game for any top down bullet hell and dungeon crawler enthusiasts. Nothing more to say.

Pros:
- Lots of diverse weapons
- Good humor & creativity
- Graphics
- Interesting plot
- Combat mechanics are good
- The developers put a lot of love into the game and clearly enjoyed making it

Cons:
- No permanent unlocks/abilities for your character, be prepared to play as the same starting character over-and-over
- Insanely grindy and not in the fun way (and I'm a veteran rogue-like player and enjoy them quite a bit)
- All weapon unlocks go straight to your RNG pool, no way to test them as you unlock them
- Boss battles are not very diverse, they are all basically just spraying bullet hell and dodging
- The camera sometimes takes weird perspectives on certain bosses which throws off my gameplay (examples #1 final dragon boss zooms WAY out #2 death wall boss feels like I'm playing Contra)
- There is no good reason starting weapons shouldn't be able to reveal wall cracks for hidden areas
- Shop costs should maybe be re-balanced, sometimes you can't earn enough to buy anything on the first floor which is silly. Or there aren't enough keys for the boxes on the first floor so you just have to destroy them for junk (hooray?!)
- Vendors do not consistently appear so your are at the mercy of RNG if you want to try something that requires a certain vendor (example, you might need the junk collector but it's possible he won't appear at all)
- Some gameplay mechanics exists that you are completely unaware about (i.e. coolness, curses, etc.)
- Weapon & item synergies exist but aren't really explained 

Overall, I see why people like the game because it is very polished and fun at first. However, honestly it's just not that fun after awhile (I put 25 hours in on PC and about 25 hours on Xbox). I find the replay-loop so tedious & grindy because there are no permanent unlocks and the other reasons I mentioned.  The only thing that changes each run is the floor layouts & vendors.  After awhile I started to just want to play something else where to feel I was making actual progress playing a game.

I would probably not recommend this game to someone because I can think of at least 5 other rogue-like games I enjoy more (better replay-loop, better unlocks, and more fun).  Do I think it's a bad game? Absolutely not. However, I wouldn't tell someone to play it even if I knew they enjoyed rogue-like games.  Just my opinion.  I bought it for $5 on a sale so I'm glad I tried it, but I won't be playing it again.

Enter the Gungeon is a fantastic bullet hell game that is a lot of fun to play. The gameplay is fast-paced and intense, with a wide variety of different weapons and items to choose from. The game's art style is also a standout feature, with a unique pixel art style that is both charming and visually striking.

One of the things I love most about Enter the Gungeon is the sheer absurdity of the game's premise. You play as a group of characters who are trying to reach the bottom of a giant, gun-filled dungeon in order to find the ultimate weapon. It's a ridiculous setup, but it works because the game is so over-the-top and doesn't take itself too seriously.

The game's music is also a standout feature. The upbeat, energetic soundtrack perfectly fits the frenetic gameplay and adds to the game's overall sense of chaos.

Overall, if you're in the mood for some good old-fashioned bullet hell action, Enter the Gungeon is the game for you. Just try not to take it too seriously – it's all in good fun.

Gungeon is a very bad game, cleverly disguised as a good one. 
For all the wonderful presentation it feels like only about 10 seconds were put into considering the actual balancing. The game effectively works on a cycle on die until you get lucky and get a gun that makes you invincible and trivialises the entire games; there is no skill in involved at any point in the loop it's purely up to chance if the game decides to let you win.
Despite having 4 playable characters unlocked at the start (with 4 more unlockable down the line) only one single character is viable for an actual run; all the others offer zero benefits and have much weaker starting gear. Hell, even the gimmick secret characters are held back by them being fundamentally useless without very specific weapon combos, which you are exceedingly unlikely to get.
There a million different weapons, yet somehow the majority of them are useless with only a few standout exceptions. The game is incredibly stingy with health meaning that if you don't get a free win weapon, it demands perfection from you at every turn, which is simply not fun. Not to mention that if you cannot leave a single resource behind for even one second, as it'll be magically stolen away from you, which completely removes any element of experimentation the game could offer. 
For a rougelike, I was expecting a ton of secrets, yet all the secrets of gungeon are just weak, pointless characters, or brutally difficult bonus floors which a). offer you very minimal reward for finishing and b). are usually impossible to access if you actually want a good run.
I can't really recommend this game to anyone, if you're new to rougelikes stay far far away from this and pick up something like Hades, Moonlighter or Risk of Rain 2 instead. If you're a veteran then... I'd still stay away from this game as all you find is a hollow shell under a lot of fancy presentation.

An amazing game destroyed by dubious game-design choices.

I had fun with this game, but I feel like it has obvious, easy-to-solve flaws.

The first thing that annoys me the most is the choice of weapons. The game has just waaaay too much choice, most of which sucks so bad that you often feel like just using your first gun anyways. This tends to make the early phases of each run slow and painful. I get that they want to make you feel like you are getting stronger slowly and progressively, but this is just stupid. I feel like taking on the challenges the game presents, but I am just put off by the prospect of crawling through the first floor of the game every time. I often feel punished for buying new guns, as it only adds trash to my roster of possible armaments and utilities. When you find the said trash in chests, you just feel punished for exploring the game and not just rushing directly to the boss chamber. It is incredibly frustrating. And why? Ideally the developer would carefully curate a set of tools for the player to have fun taking on the challenges, but this is just lazy. And why don't we even get an option of setting the game to our taste? Let me remove the fifteen reskins of shirt-throwers for god's sake.

Also, the coop in this game, let me tell you. Why force the second player into the crappy pink guy? Let the second player have some variation too, jesus. It feels like punishment to start with that nerf gun every run.

If the developer add some seriously minimal quality of life improvements to this game, I will gladly change my rating to positive, but there are just too many design choices that feel like an insult to the community.
