Had the best first floor ever on a challenge run. Got a ton of health and great items, plenty of keys. Decide to go to the secret floor. I'm dead in three rooms. Challenge mode isn't a challenge.  A challenge implies something is fun but difficult. Challenge mode is not fun or difficult. It requires no skill to win, only pure luck. Certain rooms as soon as third floor will outright kill you with no way to stop it. It's like saying "Jumping out of an airplane without a parachute and living is a challenge". Challenge mode is excessively hard and I'm just going to download a save file at 100% because I'm never going to beat challenge mode no matter how many times I've tried. 

Most of the game is amazing except challenge mode.  The fact that it's required to 100% the game means that I won't ever see the entirety of a game I BOUGHT without cheating. I paid for a game I will never see all of unless I remove all sense of accomplishment from beating the game 100%. Challenge mode alone makes me not recommend this game but there are also tables, the High Priest, and enemies that shoot through walls if they're too close to them. 99% of the game is pure awesome, but that last 1% is just complete garbage that removes all fun from the game for me. It overrides the rest of my feelings for this game and turns them in to pure anger.

Full disclosure: I bought Gungeon because I'm a huge fan of Nuclear Throne and I heard Gungeon was similar. And yes, I am writing this review because I just died in this game for the twentieth time and I'm raging hard. That being said, my problem with Gungeon isn't that it is difficult and I die all the time. Nuclear Throne was difficult. I died hundreds of times in that game before I even reached the Throne. I'm fine with dying in a game, as long as its quick and fun.

My problem with Gungeon is that it is not quick or fun. Everything about Gungeon takes too long. Spawning takes too long. Opening the inventory takes too long. Dying takes too long. Walking takes too long. Killing enemies takes too long. Losing health takes too long. Everything you can do in Gungeon takes several minutes to do. Bullets move slowly, and so do you. Floors have so many rooms that you need a teleporter to move between them, which would be fine if the floors were fun, but they're just grindfests as you build up for the bossfight.

That's another problem I have with this game: its built almost entirely around bossfights. Most of your deaths will be against the bosses, not the mobs that you spend most of the game fighting. You spend most of the game preparing for the game, not actually playing it. Its all so tedious.

Everything has a stupid, pointless animation attached to it. When you die, there's a five second long animation of a scope zeroing in on the player character. When you open the inventory, there's a three second long animation of a book opening. Why? What's the point? Who asked for this?

When I die in Gungeon, I don't want to learn from my mistakes or try again. Why would I? Trying again would cost me another hour of my time. I just want to close the game and do something else.

Ive done almost all the sidequests and completed the game with every character except for one, This action rogue like hates the player. The first few levels are full of enjoyment and a very balanced power curve. But anything past the 3rd level is honestly some of the most un-enjoyable gameplay i have ever had the experience of playing. Throughout your ENTIRE run pickups will always be scarce, thats not a problem but on the last two levels you might aswell just pretend that pickups are turned off. The final two levels where you are fighting tooth and nail to keep your healthbar from hitting zero. I have had multiple runs where literally no pickups or health drops spawned on the last two levels. Theres a mechanic that basically forces you to memorize the games boss attack patterns because when you beat a boss without taking damage it gives you a guarenteed health up. This isnt a bad thing but the fact that the game borderline forces players to do this, to counter the low pickup rate in low levels, is very VERY annoying. Its gotten to the point where I just restart runs if i get hit at all during the first or maybe second stage bosses. It might just be a skill issue on my part but I can only imagine casual players absolutly slogging through this game in order to get anywhere at all. The way you go about unlocking some things in the game is very obscure. To beat the secret boss/ "true boss" of the gungeon you need to save up your money for at least two levels leaving you very vulnerable and many weapon and items short to face such a foe. Its a very fun game but after all these hours I see the flaws and cannot look past them anymore.

Afterthought: out of all my runs I have gotten only 4 that i can think of where all my items synergized to make a whole new unique playstyle. I feel like these moments are few and far inbetween and this game just makes me want to play binding of isaac instead.

Only have two pet peeves with this game:

1º- To learn how to sell items you need to basically go online and search it out. There is no way most people figured it out on their own, that you would have to drop and item with a specific button/key on the green dude below the sewer grate. Not only that but the way you drop passive items is different from the rest, which requires you to open the map select the item and click on the top left corner of the screen where it says drop.

2º- Lack of Synergy page in the Ammonomicon. Makes no sense to go on a third party website to figure this out.
I kind of get why it's not in, due to how complex the menu would have to be, but still bothers me a little.

Regardless of those two issues I still think this game deserves a 9/10.

There's a lot to like about ETG (like the very excellent pixel art, sound design and music), but overwhelmingly it leaves me feeling like the game has no respect for my time. And yes I have put in quite a number of hours at this point.

It seems fun when you unlock things, but it also feels like you are never truly rewarded for your accomplishments, or given anything to offset the tedium of the earlygame. Everything you unlock aside from new characters just gets tossed into the RNG machine, which, at this point for me, is full of a huge number of very underwhelming items. The first bossfight more often than not will be a long and tedious fight with your starting weapon, because you need to save keys [spoiler]in order to access the secret level to increase your overall chances of success[/spoiler], and the game feels insanely stingy when it comes to actually giving you things you need, to the point of just leaving you feeling powerless, empty, and bored. This is the enduring feeling I have from playing this game, not a feeling of accomplishment, or excitement for the next run. I feel like unlockable alternate starting loadouts at least for each of the main 4 characters might have been a good way to offset some of these issues.

At this point I have unlocked all characters, killed all of their pasts, and unlocked every single purchasable item. I am currently wondering how I'm ever going to beat the [spoiler]Lich[/spoiler] with the starting characters, which is presumably how the alternate skins for the starting weapons are unlocked, but really I'm just guessing. Then I suppose there's beating the [spoiler]resourceful rat after finding him in his lair[/spoiler], which at this point I basically have no idea how to do. Unlocking the [spoiler]rat's lair[/spoiler] for the first time was an incredibly baffling and disappointing experience. All those runs, all those resources, for something like that? It didn't leave me feeling intrigued, it left me feeling frustrated and wayless, with a feeling of "uhh... what now?". I really don't like [i]having[/i] to go read somebody's guide. I want to be able to figure things out for myself. But what am I going to do, waste over 100 shells every run, running around aimlessly in that location? Doesn't sound appealing. I've heard hints about how to do it, but at this point it's just a big frustrating question mark.

Fun, special events or drops, like rainbow chests in normal runs, feel exceedingly rare. In over 250hrs of game time and nearly [i]four hundred[/i] runs, I have seen TWO rainbow chests. Secret rooms regularly feel like a total waste of the often huge amount of time [i]and[/i] ammo it can take to find them, and apparently sometimes they don't even spawn on a level, which feels like having the game spit in your face when 99% of the time, I am [i]desperate[/i] for resources, or for something interesting to happen.

I understand a bit of grind, but even with having so many things unlocked, it really feels like "back to square one" every single time. I put over 800 hours into the Isaac games and the grind never felt like this. I feel like this is a game you should only consider if you have extremely good, pro-gamer reflexes, or a huge amount of patience. Despite it all I will probably continue to play this game, but it does feel like there's wasted potential here, and that there's a more satisfying game buried somewhere inside.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

Прекрасная игра, наиграл в неё тысячи часов на плойке и прошёл на 100%. Пишу отзыв тут, потому что в пс сторе так себе система отзывов, да и сам пс стор - пятикратно переваренный кал.
EtG это смесь рогалика и буллет хелла, геймплейная суть это:
1. Уворачивайся от пуль. Тут как в этих ваших дарксоулсах: либо учишь паттерны врагов, либо вывозишь на реакции.
2. Стреляй в ответ. Да, с попаданием иногда будут проблемы. Да и у некоторых пушек с прицельной стрельбой, кхм-кхм, не очень
3. Лутайся. Сотни разных пушек и предметов. Большая часть предметов - это какая-то отсылка или пасхалка
За счёт разных вариаций лута у тебя будет получаться каждый раз уникальный ран. Иногда будет попадаться всякое говно, с которым далеко не уйдёшь. А иногда будет дикая имба, с которой наконец-то продвинешься дальше.
Короче, советую.

Update: I've finally unlocked all achievements and I've obtained the prized Finished Gun. And I still see myself playing this game for hundreds more hours. Truly a great game.

This game is a well polished combination of dungeon crawling and bullet hell. It has tremendous charm and has great humor. The game references other titles like Metroid, Dark Souls, Mega Man, etc. and has heaps of other Easter eggs.

It's difficulty may be hard for those that are new to the genre but is decent enough for those that have played either dungeon crawlers or bullet hell games. The bosses can be grueling at first but once you've poured more hours, you'll get better, trust me. Enter the Gungeon offers tons and tons of guns and items that can synergize with each other paving the way for creative approaches.

P.S. Even if you're new to this type of genre, this is a great opener. You'll enjoy more than just its great gameplay, the humor and the interaction with NPC's will be there to give you entertainment. This game is a gem.

My first roguelite ever, Enter the Gungeon took a very long time for me to be able to make sense out of. This is a pretty cruel game when you're starting out for the first time, those first 10 or so attempts where you've unlocked very little, you're still learning enemy and boss patterns, and I doubted that I'd ever get far in this game. This progression picks up slowly but surely over time, not just in the items and guns you find but in the learning curve for the game. It will take time, but this will click into place, and you will find yourself victorious soon enough.

It's not a perfect game by any means; it's sometimes buggy, some of the weapon info you're given is flat-out wrong, some weapons feel very similar to others (or just completely obselete), and there are some items and guns that turn the game into the win button. I'd also highly recommend playing this with the EtG wiki in the background, unless you're adamant that you want to find and memorise every item, gun, and synergy to learn which ones are worth the shell currency. 

Stick with this one; it's gonna be rough for a while, but after that first big hurdle, progression is going to be smooth, and hopefully you'll get as much fun out of it as I did.

Old Fashioned Butter Rolls
Prep Time: 25 minutes
Cook Time: 35 minutes
Servings: 12 rolls
Ingredients
▢2 cups self-rising flour
▢1/2 cup shortening
▢1/2 cup cold water
▢1/2 cup unsalted butter, very soft
▢1/4 cup sugar
▢1/2 teaspoon ground nutmeg (or cinnamon)
For the sauce:
▢2 cups milk
▢2/3 cup sugar
▢1 teaspoon vanilla extract
Instructions
▢
Preheat the oven to 350°F and lightly spray a 9x13-inch baking dish with nonstick cooking spray.
▢
In a large bowl, cut the shortening into the flour using a pastry blender or two forks. The goal is to get the shortening cut into tiny pea-size pieces.
▢
Add the water and stir until combined. Use your hands to gently knead the dough until it holds together.
▢
Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured surface and roll the dough into a thin rectangle that is about 10x16-inches. Spread the soft butter to cover the dough then sprinkle with the sugar and nutmeg (or cinnamon). Carefully and tightly roll the dough up jelly roll style and pinch to seal the long edge. Cut the dough into 12 even rolls and place them into the prepared dish.
Make the sauce:
▢
Combine the milk and sugar in a small pot over medium high heat. Stir until the milk just begins to bubble. Remove from the heat and stir in the vanilla. Pour the mixture over the rolls.
▢
Bake uncovered for 35 to 45 minutes or until the rolls are brown on the tops. Serve warm.

HOW DO I STOP PLAYING THIS GAME

Let me preface to say that I am not a fan of rogue-like games. I still purchased this since the reviews were good. I tried my best to enjoy this game but just couldn't. This game has further cemented my disdain for the genre.

-Lazy proceduraly generated dungeons means the levels are randomly generated by an algorithm rather than expertly handcrafted with interesting locations, memorable areas, and fun enemy placements by a designer. Instead, you get a hodge podge of nonsense thrown into a blender. This is like making a sandwich by wearing a blindfold and throwing whatever ingredient is in your fridge (bread, grape jelly, baking soda, expired tuna, half eaten sausage link, and frozen peas, whatever). Sure, its possible to get something good; but most of the time you get nonsense.

-If you die, then you have to replay the level or several levels over again (this can be +20 minutes). This is a huge waste of time if you are a gamer who values his/her time and does not like repetition. This is compounded even further by the procedurally generated dungeons which makes me even less interested in replaying after each death.

-You aren't given much of a story. Without some interesting hook to keep me invested, why should I replay these levels over and over again after each death? This genre is for players who enjoy feeling good about overcoming a challenge. For me at least, I don't care about feeling personal validation and sense of accomplishment over beating a gaming challenge. I just want to play something that is fun and not repetitive.

-Like your typical rogue-like, there is a huge luck component. You might get an easy dungeon, good guns, "cooperative" boss in one run. And then you get obliterated in the next. If you are a fan of rogue-likes (i.e. you enjoy dying a lot and repeating the same procedurally generated dungeons over and over again until you get the right combination of "git gud" and lucky RNG), then this game is up your alley. For me, i'd rather play a different game that I enjoy then keep hitting my head on this wall until I "git gud" and "git lucky".

I write this review after finally getting 100 percent completion in the game (minus some grinding achievements), so I’ve been through everything the game can throw at me.

Enter the Gungeon (EtG) is a roguelite action shooter that has you dodge waves of bullets as you descend deeper within the gungeon. You have four characters at start with four more as unlockables. The game comes with an enormous arsenal of weapons at your disposal, but no weapon is an automatic win. Gungeon is a very skill-based game, where you want to even stand a prayer at later floors you’re going to need to learn the inside and out of every enemy and every boss for any situation. It’s not like Binding of Issac where a good item or two makes the run laughable, the game will keep you on your toes the entire time. The game doesn’t go into the madness of some true bullet hells, but the difficulty will please people.

After 150 hours, I can say the game is an excellent roguelite. If you’re a fan of roguelites and/or shooters, definitely give this game a shot.

The third one ('Weird Tale') is a grind fest that takes forever. Everything else is relatively easy, though.

I gave my life to this game. I have pretty bad substance abuse issues and I was sober for a few months. I have a big problem with gaming + substances, and this game, in short, caused me to relapse. I played for 3 weeks and ignored all of my responsibilities and just got high as hell and entered the Gungeon. 

Let me get one thing straight - I fucking love this game. I literally cannot stop playing it after 100%ing it, getting all Ammonomicon entries, beating it every which way in every variation you can think of (with the exception of cursed + turbo + blessed + double challenge in a full run). 

All I want to say is beware those that can't control themselves. The Gungeon will suck you in and suck you dry and suck your funds out (because everything you buy must be Gungeon themed) and suck the life out of you until you're nothing but a dry shell bullet-kin in the Keep of the Lead Lord and ... you hear a noise? You keep hearing these noises, sometimes soft plodding, sometimes clanking, sometimes the confident stride of a man who slings Guns... you turn the corner... pew pew... and its all over. 5/5 game, also don't do drugs kids

its a good roguelike, but i personally really don't like how the game actively punishes you for strategising. this is no isaac, where even the worst of luck can be min-maxed if you play your cards right. this game deals you cards and you either use them immediately or not at all. 

you cant leave ammo on the ground for later when you need, it disappears. if all your guns are full and you get an ammo drop, sucks to be you.

get an active item from a chest, but you already have one that you want to use for the rest of the floor before you take the new one? tough luck, any item you leave in a room will disappear if you leave said room.

want to save your money to splurge on a better shop later down the line instead of spending it immediately? too bad, you'd better buy what you want right now, because prices increase the further you go, you'll never have enough for more than one item.

oh, and don't forget the DPS cap for bosses, which makes sure that it doesn't matter how good your build is, you'll never feel powerful, and will always use a ton of ammo. glass cannons be damned.

all of this makes each run feel very linear, there's very little room for actually making your own plays and decisions. you just have to always move forward or not at all, which feels really strange for this genre. It's like the game is rushing you.

Enter The Gungeon is my favourite roguelike game ever. It has tons of replayability and secrets to discover. and with every new character and NPC you unlock comes a different way to experience the game to somehow give it even more of a varied experience. Of course, as with all good things comes the bad. There definitely are way too many items in the game. A lot of the items are good and some to the extent where simply having that item turns the entire game into a cakewalk but more then half the items in the game are trash. If you're just playing the vanilla experience then most of your runs will be plagued by bad items and even your skill wont be enough to save you. I always play on rainbow mode which makes it so that you only get 1 item per floor but you basically get to choose what it is from a randomised selection. This is the only way to get more actual good runs then not; because once again, there is too much trash in this game.

Closing thoughts: Someone should create a mod that allows you to pick which items will appear in the game and which don't. Not so much for the purpose of every run being a total cheese, but more to even out the loot pool. I still love this game and will likely still play it every day.


Side note: I have checked out some of the mods for this game and they aren't low quality stuff either. The loot pool thing is still a problem but once you get the mod items, it's worth it. Shoutout to the Modders!

First played this on Xbox, then on Switch, now on PC. Hundreds of hours probably total,  this is one of my all time favorite games. I like old style, arcade difficult games, it's what I grew up playing. To me, this is the most replayable Rogue-like I've played. The challenge is significant, and each time you never know what you'll get to combat it. There's just a huge batch of really unique weapons and items that are well thought out and so fun to try out.

Even with an amazing weapon or items, your skill alone is what will get you past some of the really hard bosses and enemies, but the stuff you find can give you the edge you need to get through. It seems like you get better stuff the better you play too, idk how much the RNG is actually affected by how good you play, but it feels like it is at least somewhat. 

Now, if you're incredible at this game, you can get all the way through with pretty basic weapons, it's definitely possible, but it's very hard to get that good. I think a lot of people who have played it have never completed the whole gungeon even once, but it's very enjoyable even if you die over and over. Overall, if you're looking for something that feels old school and challenging in a good way, this is about as good as it gets.

Like a lot of games, it lacks polish and is style over substance.
Plays like a Binding of Isaac clone that makes relatively few changes to gameplay. Which in itself would be welcome.
However, there is a lack of balance that emphasizes quirkiness in jokes and references at the expense of gameplay.

For this type of game, ideally you should feel like every hit you take is due to player error and avoidable. Does not seem ot be the case.
The camera is often one of the greatest enemies. Instead of always being able to see the entire room, you can only the direction you are aiming at, with the character often on the periphery of the screen. It is not unusual to get hit by enemies you don't even know exist.

The controls are another foe. One of the key mechanics are "blanks" which serve as bombs from bullet-hell games, clearing the screen. However, the control is hard-locked to pressing both analog sticks in at the same time, which is difficult at best when you are moving the sticks at all times. 

There is a wide range of weapons, but half of them seem to be useless jokes and there is no way to easily tell if a new weapon is actually any good, as they lack viewable stats or ranks. 

Instead of organically unlocking new items by playing the game, all of the new items are purchased with in-game currency. Which would be fine, but the currency can only be acquired by defeating bosses. Getting hit once by a boss drastically reduces the rewards and makes earning credits a tedious slough instead of a byproduct of enjoying the game.

It is kind of a shame, there is potential here, but it buried under a lot of weird decisions. When the game is fun, it is great; dodging bullet-hell style barrages and taking enemies out one by one. But it too often becomes a frustrating experience.

This game has provided me what feels like endless hours of entertainment, and an ever changing experience run to run. Even still I find room layouts I have yet to encounter, and I'm over 300 hours in! Not to mention the incredible variety of weaponry at the player's disposal. The procedural generation means that no matter how long you play, no two runs will ever be the same. The sound design and music that acompanies every experience really enriches the game-play. And ontop of it all, I have yet to see another game of it's caliber as far as AI is concerned, the tracking and movement is out of this world, and allows for a challenging, yet fulfilling fight in every room. As far as this game goes, I rate it an 11 out of 10, this is a Roguelike that I would recommend to beginners and experts alike!

Long list of why it's good:
- EtG is a bullet hell that is easy to play but hard to master. Also has Witty humor and neat lore.
- Extremely replayable and has co-op (FYI it's 2 player, one plays on keyboard other on controller)
- I have about 200 hours in it, and still have not found / unlocked everything in the game (Tons of content)
- Amazing soundtrack to back the game up.
- The game looks cute and has fun mechanics. Also a ton of references to other medias.
- It makes you feel like a badass. 
- Tons of convoluted and fun secrets to find some of which will blow your mind! 
- Was made because the devs had to sit in a parking lot for 6 hours.
- The devs (seemingly) made this game with the idea of more bang for you buck because it really shows.


BTW The game doesn't exactly tell you exactly how to find some secrets or where to find something so you'll feel like either a genius or a retard depending if you looked up a guide or not.
If you play co-op your experience will be more difficult so don't think your homie is gonna help carry you.
The game -If you're new and still reading this- has tons of hidden content underneath the surface and definitely worth the money in my opinion!

This game is pretty good.  It checks a lot of the rogue-lite boxes: difficulty scaling, unlock tons of items, and a primary form of progression being through player understanding of the game rather than permanently improving your starting character.

That said, rogue-lites are my favorite genre and I have a number of nitpicks that prevent this from being one that I can really enjoy coming back to.
Pacing of the game is just slow, but not in a way that I could call methodical.  Gun firing speed is slow.  Bullets move slowly.  Reload is slow.  The rooms are very large compared to character walk speed which makes navigation slow.  Forget fighting through a floor with a wildly inaccurate gun, it takes to long just to walk to the end of a room.
Also.... more on the guns being inaccurate.  How are you going to make a skill-based shooter game and not have the bullets go where the player is directing them?  This is the most frustrating point for me.

Runs are also way more RNG dependent on good gun drops than most other rogues that depend on intra-run items.  This is largely due to the fact that the guns have limited supplies of ammo and the starter guns are trash (mostly due to their inaccuracy). If either the starter guns had complete accuracy, making them have a reasonable baseline value, or ammo was less restrictive, I would have an easier time forgiving this grievance.

As it stands, you need to get good guns to get very far (yes you can kill bosses with basic weapons but holy goddamn is it unbelievably and unbearably slow), and it's a grind to get to the good guns, particularly since the unlock order is pretty hard set in stone.

All of that said, the upside to this game is pretty significant if you can stomach the slow early game.  It's definitely a hardcore roguelite so it kind of breaks my heart that I can't look past its faults.

I dropped EtG at launch due to how miserable the game felt from run to run: stingy drops across the board forced you to rely on your starter pistol to clear floors until you either made it to the mines and died or found a boss melter and got a shot at the dragun, to say nothing of the barren hell you'd have to slog through trying to clear the alt path. Despite the fluidity of the moment-to-moment gameplay and the wonderful feel of everything, playing the game itself wore me down way too fast.

Come back a few years later and, would you look at that, they've fixed the drops! EtG is a blast now, with about a dozen different secret floors, bosses, and so-on added since last I played. The improved drop rates for keys and high-tier chests means I can activate synergies more easily, and challenge characters like the Gunslinger and Paradox turn the game into a hectic playground of weird and wonderful weapons. Now, sure, I still resent the game for making me learn to play Punch Out! but I'm more than willing to let that slide if it means I get to fight the Advanced Dragun.

The game good! Better than Hades at-least. My main problem with it is the early game is just too boring, the first floor simply has too little content, and I feel like the game is backwards in that sense, The last areas have the most content compared to the other floors in the game, as-well with the coolest content.
This might sound a bit goofy but hear me out. In ETG at the start of every run you are on the first floor, which makes sense, and you are only at the last floor every 15-20ish runs. So why does the last floor have so much content compared to every other floor, if the player is there only a fraction amount of time? Most rogue-like games have this problem, and I feel like it disincentives new runs, as you will need to go though the same easy first floor again and again at the start of it. There should be variants to the first areas, spice it up a bit if players will be there for the majority of their time with your game. Don't make the content 'cool' necessarily, as then the start would be more fun than the end, just make it not be the same every time. Hades did this a bit (contradicting a bit with what I said at the very start), and I feel like it made it a better game! 

(Also I feel like the pacing is bad (partially because of  the reason stated above))

This game if fun, but I can't see myself getting the true TRUE ending, so I'm sorry ETG, but you're a 6.8/10 for me.


(ALSO! I have probably not found the 'cool' content of this game, but I have played shy of 70 hours I think, and if I need to invest more time into that, to get the best content, that sorry, I can't do that)

(ALSO ALSO! I don't think this means much, but my favourite Rogue-like is Noita)
